The '''Daniel Guggenheim Medal''' is an American [[engineering]] award, established by [[Daniel Guggenheim|Daniel]] and [[Harry Guggenheim]]. The medal is considered to be one of the greatest honors that can be presented for a lifetime of work in [[aeronautics]].<ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Home.aspx History of Guggenheim medal]</ref> Recipients have included American and international individuals from aeronautical corporations, governments, and academia.
Since 1929 it has been given annually to persons who make notable achievements in the advancement of aeronautics.<ref>[http://www.aiaa.org/content.cfm?pageid=401 Guggenheim award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050424160935/http://www.aiaa.org/content.cfm?pageid=401 |date=2005-04-24 }}</ref> It is awarded jointly by the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]], the [[Society of Automotive Engineers]], the [[American Helicopter Society]], and the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]]. The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics administers the award.
==Recipients== The winners are listed below along with their award citation and year.
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%" ! width="15%" | Year ! width="20%" | Name ! width="*" class="unsortable" | Award citation ! width="5%" class="unsortable" | Reference |- | 1929 | align="center" | [[Orville Wright]] | ''For the design and construction, with his brother now deceased, of the first successful engine-propelled airplane.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201929.pdf Orville Wright - 1929 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1930 | align="center" | [[Ludwig Prandtl]] | ''For pioneer and creative work in the theory of dynamics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201930.pdf Ludwig Prandtl - 1930 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1931 | align="center" | [[Frederick W. Lanchester]] | ''For contributions to the fundamental theory of [[aerodynamics]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201931.pdf Frederick W. Lanchester - 1931 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1932 | align="center" | [[Juan de la Cierva]] | ''For development of the theory and practice of the [[autogiro]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201932.pdf Juan de la Cierva - 1932 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1933 | align="center" | [[Jerome Clarke Hunsaker]] | ''For contributions to the science of aerodynamics, to the science and art of aircraft design, and to the practical construction and utilization of rigid airships.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201933.pdf Jerome C. Hunsaker - 1933 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1934 | align="center" | [[William E. Boeing]] | ''For successful pioneering and achievement in aircraft manufacturing and air transport.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201934.pdf William E. Boeing - 1934 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1935 | align="center" | [[William F. Durand]] | ''For notable achievement as pioneer in laboratory research and theory of aeronautics; distinguished contributions to the theory and development of aircraft [[propeller]]s.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201935.pdf William F. Durand - 1935 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1936 | align="center" | [[George W. Lewis]] | ''For pioneer and creative work in the theory of dynamics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201936.pdf George W. Lewis - 1936 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1937 | align="center" | [[Hugo Eckener]] | ''For notable contributions to transoceanic air transport and to international cooperation in aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201937.pdf Hugo Eckener - 1937 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1938 | align="center" | [[Roy Fedden|Alfred H. Fedden]] | ''For contributions to the development of aircraft engine design and for the specific design of the [[Sleeve valve|sleeve-valve]] aircraft engine.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201938.pdf Alfred Fedden - 1938 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1939 | align="center" | [[Donald W. Douglas]] | ''For outstanding contributions to the design and construction of transport airplanes.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201939.pdf Donald W. Douglas - 1939 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1940 | align="center" | [[Glenn L. Martin]] | ''For contributions to aeronautical development and the production of many types of aircraft of high performance.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201940.pdf Glenn L. Martin - 1940 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1941 | align="center" | [[Juan T. Trippe]] | ''For the development and successful operation of oceanic air transport.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201941.pdf Juan T. Trippe - 1941 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1942 | align="center" | [[James H. Doolittle]] | ''For notable achievements in the advancements of both the art and the science of aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201942.pdf James H. Doolittle - 1942 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1943 | align="center" | [[Edmund T. "Eddie" Allen]] | ''For major contributions to aeronautics leading to important advances in airplane design, flight research, and airline operation; particularly for the presentation of new methods for operational control and for the development of scientific and systematic methods in the flight testing of aircraft for basic design and performance data.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201943.pdf Edmund T. Allen - 1943 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1944 | align="center" | [[Lawrence D. Bell]] | ''For achievement in design and construction of military air craft and for outstanding contributions to the methods of production.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201944.pdf Lawrence D. Bell - 1944 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1945 | align="center" | [[Theodore P. Wright]] | ''For outstanding contributions to the development of civil and military aircraft, and for notable achievement in assuring the success of our wartime aircraft production program.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201945.pdf Theodore P. Wright - 1945 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1946 | align="center" | [[Frank Whittle]] | ''For pioneering the development of [[turbojet]] propulsion of aircraft.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201946.pdf Frank Whittle - 1946 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1947 | align="center" | [[d:Q36071124|Lester Durand Gardner]] | ''For outstanding achievement in advancing aeronautics, particularly for his conception and organization of the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics|Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201947.pdf Lester D. Gardner - 1947 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1948 | align="center" | [[Leroy R. Grumman]] | ''For outstanding achievement in successfully advancing aircraft design, both for Naval and peacetime use.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201948.pdf Leroy R. Grumman - 1948 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1949 | align="center" | [[Edward Pearson Warner]] | ''For pioneering in research and a continuous record of contributions to the art and science of aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201949.pdf Edward P. Warner - 1949 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1950 | align="center" | [[Hugh L. Dryden]] | ''For outstanding leadership in aeronautical research and fundamental contributions to aeronautical science.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201950.pdf Hugh L. Dryden - 1950 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1951 | align="center" | [[Igor I. Sikorsky]] | ''For a lifetime of outstanding contributions to aeronautics, including pioneering with multi-engine airplanes, [[flying boat]]s, [[Amphibious aircraft|amphibians]] and [[helicopter]]s.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201951.pdf Igor I. Sikorsky - 1951 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1952 | align="center" | [[Geoffrey de Havilland]] | ''For forty years of pioneering in military and commercial aircraft and the development of long-range jet transport.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201952.pdf Geoffrey de Havilland - 1952 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1953 | align="center" | [[Charles Lindbergh]] | ''For pioneering achievements in flight and air navigation.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201953.pdf Charles Lindbergh - 1953 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1954 | align="center" | [[C. D. Howe|Clarence D. Howe]] | ''For initiating and organizing commercial air routes and services, promoting aeronautical research, development and production of aircraft and engines, and advancing the art of aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201954.pdf Clarence D. Howe - 1954 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1955 | align="center" | [[Theodore von Karman]] | ''For long-continued leadership in the development of aerodynamic theory and its application to the practical problems of flight, in education in the aeronautical sciences, and in stimulating international cooperation in aeronautical research.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Medalist%20PDF/MEDALIST%20FOR%201955.pdf Theodore von Karman - 1955 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1956 | align="center" | [[Frederick B. Rentschler]] | ''For a wide range of major achievements throughout a lifetime devoted to aviation, with specific reference to his many notable contributions to the vital aircraft engine field'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Rentschler Frederick B. Rentschler - 1956 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1957 | align="center" | [[Arthur E. Raymond]] | ''For the development of a long line of successful civil and military aircraft and for notable contributions to aeronautics in public service.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Raymond Arthur E. Raymond - 1957 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1958 | align="center" | [[William Littlewood]] | ''For leadership and continuous personal participation over a quarter of a century in developing the equipment and operating techniques of air transport.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Littlewood William Littlewood - 1958 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1959 | align="center" | [[George Edwards (aviation)|George Edwards]] | ''For a lifetime devoted to the design of military and commercial aircraft, culminating in the successful introduction into worldwide commercial service of the first turbine-powered propeller-driven aircraft.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Edwards George Edwards - 1959 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1960 | align="center" | [[Grover Loening]] | ''For a lifetime devoted to the development of aeronautics in America.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=loening Grover Loening - 1960 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1961 | align="center" | [[Jerome F. Lederer]] | ''For his lifelong dedication to the cause of flight safety and his constant and untiring efforts to reduce the hazards of aviation.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Lederer Jerome F. Lederer - 1961 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1962 | align="center" | [[James H. Kindelberger]] | ''For technical and industrial leadership in producing excellent aircraft and space equipment, from early fighters to the [[North American X-15|X-15]] space plane.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Kindelberger James H. Kindelberger - 1962 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1963 | align="center" | [[James S. McDonnell]] | ''For lifetime contribution of outstanding nature in the design and development of military aircraft, and for pioneer work in space technology.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=McDonnell James S. McDonnell - 1963 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1964 | align="center" | [[Robert H. Goddard]] | ''For pioneering in rocket development and astronautics, including the first liquid-propelled rocket flight, and contributions toward aero-dynamically applicable reaction engines.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Goddard Robert H. Goddard - 1964 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1965 | align="center" | [[Sydney Camm]] | ''For over fifty years of continuous dedication to the design of military aircraft, and pioneering of many new concepts and the creation of many successful aircraft representative of the best tradition of British design skills.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Camm Sydney Camm - 1965 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1966 | align="center" | [[Charles S. Draper]] | ''For contributions to aeronautical education and significant developments in new fields of aircraft instrumentation, in particular for pioneering inertial- guidance techniques making possible en route navigation independently of earth references; for over twenty-five years of leadership in the technology of control and guidance of flight vehicles, and with the training of a large number of engineers in this vital field of aeronautics and astronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=draper Charles S. Draper - 1966 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1967 | align="center" | [[George S. Schairer]] | ''For his many contributions to the achievement of outstanding progress in subsonic/light, and in the promise of [[supersonic]] flight, and in the equipment and methods for space exploration.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Schairer George S. Schairer - 1967 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1968 | align="center" | [[H. M. Horner]] | ''For his lifelong dedication and significant contributions to the advancement of modern aviation through the development and production of an outstanding series of aircraft powerplants and spacecraft propulsion engines.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=horner H. M. Horner - 1968 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1969 | align="center" | [[H. Julian Allen]] | ''For outstanding courage, leadership and pioneering foresight that contributed outstandingly to civil and military aviation, including the evolution of the jet transport; and for his broad counsel and support to government and industry during a distinguished career.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Allen H. Julian Allen - 1969 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1970 | align="center" | [[Jakob Ackeret]] | ''For original and outstanding contributions to aerodynamics, aviation and engineering education.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=ackeret Jakob Ackeret - 1970 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1971 | align="center" | [[Archibald Russell]] | ''For his personal devotion and many contributions to aircraft engineering and design and particularly for his outstanding leadership of the Bristol team in the development of the Anglo-French [[Concorde]] Supersonic Transport Aircraft.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=russell Archibald E. Russell - 1971 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1972 | align="center" | [[William C. Mentzer]] | ''For manifold accomplishments in airline engineering, maintenance and economic disciplines, which accomplishments contributed significantly to the achievement of today’s civil air transportation systems.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=mentzer William C. Mentzer - 1972 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1973 | align="center" | [[William M. Allen]] | ''For outstanding courage, leadership and pioneering foresight that contributed outstandingly to civil and military aviation, including the evolution of the jet transport; and for his broad counsel and support to government and industry during a distinguished career.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=allen William M. Allen - 1973 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1974 | align="center" | [[Floyd L. Thompson]] | ''For farsighted development of men and facilities and for decisive leadership of research that provided technological foundations for manned flight beyond the speed of sound, safe re-entry of spacecraft, and successful exploration of space.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Thompson Floyd L. Thompson - 1974 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1975 | align="center" | [[Dwane L. Wallace]] | ''For his many engineering, management and leadership contributions in the development of general aviation from a novelty forty years ago to a key part of the world’s transportation system today.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=wallace Duane L. Wallace - 1975 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1976 | align="center" | [[Marcel Dassault]] | ''For notable achievement in development, production and marketing of many types of aircraft of high performance and outstanding leadership in world aviation.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Dassault Marcel Dassault - 1976 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1977 | align="center" | [[Cyrus R. Smith]] | ''For lifetime contribution of outstanding nature in the design and development of military aircraft, and for pioneer work in space technology.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=smith Cyrus R. Smith - 1977 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1978 | align="center" | [[Edward H. Heinemann]] | ''For outstanding achievement in the innovative design of military airplanes which are noted for longevity of service, versatility of tasks, simplicity of design, high performance and elegance of line.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Heinemann Edward H. Heinemann - 1978 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1979 | align="center" | [[Gerhard Neumann]] | ''For the development of highly efficient aircraft engines for commercial and military purposes, including creation of one of the first successful [[turbofan]] engines which contributed significantly to the efficiency and success of the airline industry.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=neumann Gerhard Neumann - 1979 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1980 | align="center" | [[Edward Curtis Wells]] | ''For his outstanding contributions to the management concepts for the development of complex aerospace systems, and for his significant personal accomplishments in the design and production of a long line of the world’s most famous commercial and military aircraft.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Wells Edward Wells - 1980 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1981 | align="center" | [[Clarence Johnson]] | ''For his brilliant design of a wide range of pace-setting, commercial, combat and reconnaissance aircraft, and for his innovative management techniques which developed these aircraft in record time at minimum cost.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=johnson Clarence Johnson - 1981 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1982 | align="center" | [[David S. Lewis, Jr.]] | ''For his long-standing contributions to aviation and national defense, and his untiring efforts toward the development of superior aircraft.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Lewis David S. Lewis - 1982 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1983 | align="center" | [[Nicholas J. Hoff]] | ''For a lifetime of significant contributions to the theory and practice of aeronautical structures design as an outstanding engineering scholar and educator.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Hoff Nicholas J. Hoff - 1983 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1984 | align="center" | [[Thomas H. Davis]] | ''For outstanding achievements in the development of an airline, of unique general aviation services; and of personnel training techniques, accomplished continuously during a period of more than 40 years.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Davis Thomas H. Davis - 1984 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1985 | align="center" | [[Thornton Wilson]] | ''For a lifetime contribution to the successful development of commercial and military aircraft and for his outstanding leadership and management skills.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=wilson Thornton A. Wilson - 1985 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1986 | align="center" | [[Hans W. Liepmann]] | ''For outstanding leadership in fluid mechanics research and education. His influence contributed significantly to the development of a generation of outstanding leaders in the field.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=liepmann Hans W. Liepmann - 1986 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1987 | align="center" | [[Paul B. MacCready - 1987 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1988 | align="center" | [[J. R. D. Tata]] | ''For a lifetime of significant contributions to aviation, for his pioneering work in developing commercial air travel in India and Asia, and for his leadership in establishing Air India as a major international link between Asia and the rest of the world.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=tata J. Weick - 1989 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1990 | align="center" | [[Joseph F. Sutter]] | ''For outstanding engineering achievement, management and leadership in the innovative development of three generations of commercial jet aircraft — in particular the [[Boeing 747|747]] — and his contribution to the enhancement of safety in air and space.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=sutter Joseph F. Sutter - 1990 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1991 | align="center" | [[Hans P. von Ohain]] | ''For pioneering the development of turbojet propulsion resulting in the first flight of a jet-powered aircraft in 1939 and his lifetime achievements in aeronautical propulsion dynamics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=von%20Ohain Hans P. von Ohain - 1991 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1992 | align="center" | [[Bernard L. Koff]] | ''For continuing leadership in the aircraft gas turbine industry producing many innovative and technological breakthroughs in material and design.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=koff Bernard L. Koff - 1992 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1993 | align="center" | [[Ludwig Boelkow]] | ''For visionary leadership and innovation in the design of [[rotorcraft]], light aircraft, missiles and space systems.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Boelkow Ludwig Boelkow - 1993 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1994 | align="center" | [[Helmut H. Korst]] | ''For a legacy of developments in aeronautics where none previously existed; for mentoring a cascade of students and colleagues dedicated to the art and science of fluid mechanics and for a lifetime of inspiration and leadership to the international engineering community.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Korst Helmut H. Seamans - 1995 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1996 | align="center" | [[William R. Sears]] | ''For lifelong contributions to aeronautics in industry and academia from the aerodynamics of the [[flying wing]] to the invention of the adaptive [[wind tunnel]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Sears William R. Sears - 1996 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1997 | align="center" | [[Abe Silverstein]] | ''For technical contributions and visionary leadership in advancing the technology of aircraft and propulsion performance, and for the foresight in establishing the [[Project Mercury|Mercury]] and [[Project Gemini|Gemini]] manned space flight activities.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Silverstein Abe Silverstein - 1997 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1998 | align="center" | [[Richard Coar]] | ''For outstanding leadership and innovative contributions in providing advanced aeronautical and space propulsion systems.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Coar Richard Coar - 1998 Medalist]</ref> |- | 1999 | align="center" | [[Frank E. Marble]] | ''For major fundamental theoretical and experimental contributions to the field of internal aerodynamics, [[combustion]] and propulsion especially with respect to gas turbines and rockets, and educating generations of leaders in industry and academia.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Marble Frank E. Marble - 1999 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2000 | align="center" | [[William Hayward Pickering|William H. Pickering]] | ''For a distinguished career that pioneered and shaped the exploration of our solar system and for extraordinary contribution to engineering and science.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Pickering William H. Pickering - 2000 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2001 | align="center" | [[Richard T. Whitcomb]] | ''For seminal contributions in aeronautics, including the development of the [[Area rule]], [[Supercritical airfoil]], and [[Wingtip device|Winglet]] concept, which are the basis for modern aerodynamic design.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Whitcomb Richard T. Whitcomb - 2001 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2002 | align="center" | [[John G. Borger]] | ''For significant pioneering contributions to aircraft and the airline industry from flying boats to jet aircraft.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Borger John G. Borger - 2002 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2003 | align="center" | [[Holt Ashley]] | ''For pioneering contributions to research, education and engineering in [[aeroelasticity]], unsteady aerodynamics and aircraft design.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Ashley Holt Ashley - 2003 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2004 | align="center" | [[Courtland Perkins]] | ''For outstanding contributions to aeronautics in research and teaching in stability and control, and superlative leadership at the national and international levels.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Perkins Courtland Perkins - 2004 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2005 | align="center" | [[Eugene E. Covert]] | ''For exemplary leadership in aeronautics teaching and research, development of significant state-of-the-art aerodynamic testing techniques, and outstanding contributions to public service.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Covert Eugene E. Covert - 2005 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2006 | align="center" | [[Robert Loewy]] | ''For pioneering contributions to rotary-wing aeroelasticity and unsteady aerodynamics which had an enormous influence on rotary-wing technology and his contributions to education and public service in aeronautics.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=loewy Robert Loewy - 2006 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2007 | align="center" | [[Alexander H. Flax]] | ''For outstanding contributions to aerospace engineering in aeroelasticity, unsteady aerodynamics and flight mechanics, and for exceptional leadership of engineering organizations including service to the [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://www.guggenheimmedal.org/Pages/Medalists.aspx?Title=Flax Alexander Flax - 2007 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2008 | align="center" | [[Earl Dowell]] | ''For pioneering contributions to nonlinear aeroelasticity, structural dynamics and unsteady aerodynamics which had a significant influence on aeronautics and for contributions to education and public service in aerospace engineering.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://prattpress.pratt.duke.edu/dowell-wins-award Earl Dowell - 2008 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2009 | align="center" | [[Arthur E. Bryson]] | ''For a lifetime of seminal contributions to real systems, creating and applying practical optimal control and estimation techniques to airplanes, rotorcraft, and missiles.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://aa.stanford.edu/news/brysonAward.php Arthur E. Bryson - 2009 Medalist]</ref> |- | 2010 | align="center" | [[Robert H. Liebeck]] | ''For distinguished engineering as evidenced by the conception and development of Liebeck airfoils and [[Blended wing body|Blended Wing Body aircraft]].'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2010/liebeck-guggenheim.html Liebeck to receive Guggenheim Medal]</ref> |- | 2011 | align="center" | [[Burt Rutan]] | ''For a distinguished career of highly innovative and successful flight vehicles ranging from home-built designed to Voyager and SpaceShipOne.'' | align="center" | |- | 2012 | align="center" | [[Frank D. Robinson]] | ''For conception, design, and manufacture of a family of quiet, affordable, reliable, and versatile helicopters.'' | align="center" | |- | 2013 | align="center" | [[Abraham Karem]] | ''For a lifetime of innovative fixed and rotary wing unmanned vehicle designs.'' | align="center" | |- | 2014 | align="center" | [[Alan Mulally]] | ''For leadership in the creation, design, development, and manufacture of commercial airplanes, exemplified by the Boeing 777.'' | align="center" | |- | 2015 | align="center" | [[Antony Jameson]] | ''For exceptional contributions to algorithmic innovation and the development of computational fluid dynamic codes that have made important contributions to aircraft design.'' | align="center" | <ref>[http://aa.stanford.edu/news-events/news/antony-jameson-joins-orville-wright-and-other-aerial-pioneers-winning-guggenheim Antony Jameson - 2015 Medalist]</ref> |}

revision.text:
[[File:Assassination attempt on Hendrik Verwoerd 2.jpg|thumb|David Pratt is overpowered after he shoots [[Hendrik Verwoerd]]]] '''David Beresford Pratt''' (1 October 1908 – 1 October 1961) was a South African businessman who shot [[South Africa|South African]] [[Prime Minister of South Africa|Prime Minister]] [[Hendrik Verwoerd]] in 1960. Verwoerd survived, but was killed six years later by [[Dimitri Tsafendas]].
==Life== Pratt was a wealthy businessman and farmer of British descent. He qualified as a chartered accountant at the [[University of Cambridge]], [[England]]. He suffered from epilepsy from an early age and was a loner at school. Both of Pratt's marriages failed. There is evidence that he suffered from his first serious bout of depression in 1946 after his divorce from Mary Hatrick. His second marriage, to Patty van Heijningen, was not successful either.
In 1954, shortly after the birth of their first child, Pratt claimed to have received a message which he should convey to South Africa. He was boarded and diagnosed as suffering from “grandiose delusions of the political saviour type”. Pratt was almost constantly in psychiatric treatment. His Dutch wife feared for her safety because he threatened her. In the beginning of 1958 she left him and returned to [[The Hague]], taking their two children with her. He followed her with a gun in his pocket but was apprehended at [[Amsterdam Airport]]. His condition worsened and he became manic. His neurologist, Dr.Chesler, urged his sister to have a ''curator bonis'' (legal guardian) appointed for him because he could no longer manage his affairs properly. He desperately tried to win his wife back. When that failed, he attempted to kidnap his little daughter during a ski holiday. As he became more desperate about his marital problems, Pratt tried to commit suicide on three different occasions. It appears that Pratt’s paranoid condition was reinforced by the escalation of the political conflict after the [[Sharpeville massacre]].
==Assassination attempt==
On 9 April 1960, Pratt shot South African Prime Minister [[Hendrik Verwoerd]] twice, at point blank range, with a .22 pistol. Verwoerd, who had been opening the Union Exposition in Milner Park, Johannesburg, was rushed to hospital, and within two months had made a complete recovery. Pratt was arrested at the scene and taken to the Marshall Square police station, and then to the Forensic Medical Laboratory. He appeared for a preliminary hearing in the Johannesburg Magistrates' Court on 20 and 21 July 1960, once it was clear that the Verwoerd's injuries were not fatal.
Pratt claimed he had been shooting 'the epitome of [[apartheid]]'. The court accepted the medical reports submitted to it by five different psychiatrists, all of which confirmed that Pratt lacked legal capacity and could not be held criminally liable for having shot the prime minister. On 26 September 1960, he was committed to a mental hospital in [[Bloemfontein]].
==Death== On the first of October 1961, his fifty-third birthday, and shortly before his parole was to be considered, he committed suicide.<ref>Wolf, Loammi (2012). "[http://www.litnet.co.za/Article/david-beresford-pratt-die-mens-agter-die-sluipmoordenaar David Beresford Pratt: die mens agter die sluipmoordpoging]" (in Afrikaans). ''LitNet Akademies'' '''9''' (3).</ref><ref>Maisels, Isie (1998). ''A Life at Law: The Memoirs of I.A. Maisels, QC''. pp. 102-107.</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pratt, David}} [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:Failed assassins]] [[Category:South African assassins]]

revision.text:
{{infobox company | name = EBA Clearing S.A.S | logo = | type = [[Société par actions simplifiée]] | fate = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|1998|6}} | founder = [[Euro Banking Association]] | defunct = | location_city = [[Paris]] | location_country = [[France]] | key_people = | industry = [[Finance]] | products = [[Clearing house (finance)|Clearing House]], [[Payment service provider]], [[Payment system]]s | revenue = | owner = 53 major European payment banks<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abe.org/The-Shareholders-N=Shareholders-L=EN.aspx |title=Shareholder banks |publisher=EBA Clearing}}</ref> | num_employees = | homepage = {{URL |https://www.ebaclearing.eu/}} }} '''EBA Clearing''' is a provider of pan-European payment infrastructure wholly owned by shareholders that consist of major European banks.
It owns and operates major payment infrastructure in Europe for Euro payments between banks. This includes [[#EURO1|EURO1]] for high value payments system, [[#STEP1|STEP1]], a payment system for single euro payments for small and medium-sized banks, and [[#STEP2|STEP2]], a [[Pan-European Automated Clearing House]] (PE-ACH). It also operates the RT1 system for instant payments due to launch in November 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.finextra.com/pressarticle/71059/swiftnet-instant-to-provide-access-to-eba-clearings-rt1-system |title=SwiftNet Instant to provide access to EBA Clearing’s RT1 system |publisher=FinExtra |date=October 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Kimberley |last=Long |date= July 28, 2016 |url=https://www.euromoney.com/article/b12kpl5cdh8fms/competition-questions-arise-over-mastercards-vocalink-buy-out |title=Competition questions arise over MasterCard’s VocaLink buy-out |publisher=Euromoney}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.it-finanzmagazin.de/echtzeitzahlungen-ab-november-2018-swiftnet-instant-ermoeglicht-zugang-zum-rt1-system-von-eba-clearing-58599/ |title=Echtzeitzahlungen ab November 2018: SWIFTNet Instant gibt Zugang zum RT1-System von EBA Clearing |trans-title=Real-time payments in November 2018: SWIFTNet Instant gives access to EBA Clearing's RT1 system |date=11 October 2017 |publisher=IT Finanzmagazin}}</ref> Both EURO1 and STEP2 have been identified as Systemically Important Payment Systems (SIPS) by the [[European Central Bank]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2014/html/pr140821.en.html |title=ECB identifies systemically important payments systems |date=21 August 2014 |website=European Central Bank}}</ref>
The organisation is based in [[Paris]] and has representative offices in [[Brussels]], [[Frankfurt]] and [[Milan]].
==History== EBA Clearing was founded in June 1998 by the [[Euro Banking Association]] (EBA) and is owned by the major payment banks operating in Europe.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ebaclearing.eu/about-eba-clearing/at-a-glance/the-company/|title=About EBA CLEARING|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ebaclearing.eu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thepaypers.com/payments-general/eba-clearing-irish-payment-services-organisation-launch-step2-irish-service/745492-27 |title=EBA Clearing, Irish Payment Services Organisation launch STEP2 Irish service |date=October 12, 2011 |publisher=ThePaypers}}</ref>
Its initial mission was to create and operate the clearing and settlement system for high value euro transactions, [[#EURO1|EURO1]], which the EBA had transferred to EBA Clearing at the launch of the [[Eurosystem]] in 1999. Besides EURO1, EBA Clearing also owns and operates [[#STEP1|STEP1]], a payment system for single euro payments for small and medium-sized banks, and [[#STEP2|STEP2]], a [[Pan-European Automated Clearing House]] (PE-ACH) for Euro-denominated retail payments. In March 2013, EBA CLEARING launched [[#MyBank|MyBank]], an e-authorisation solution for online payments, which is geared at facilitating the growth of e-commerce across Europe.<ref name=":0" />
In October 2017, banks from nine countries agreed to join RT1, EBA Clearing’s pan-European infrastructure for [[instant payments]] in Euro, on its go-live date in November 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://ibsintelligence.com/eba-clearing-joined-coalition-banks-instant-payments/ |title=EBA Clearing joined by coalition of banks for instant payments |date=October 11, 2017 |publisher=IBS Intelligence }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bankingtech.com/1033172/instant-payments-in-europe-moving-from-theory-to-practice/ |date=17 October 2017 |title=Instant payments in Europe: moving from theory to practice |publisher=Banking Technology }}</ref>
==Payment systems==
=== EURO1 === EURO1 is a [[Real-time gross settlement|RTGS-equivalent]] large-value payment system that settles single Euro transactions of high priority and urgency, and primarily of large amount. EURO1 operates on a multilateral net basis, meaning that it continuously adjusts the accounts of the participant banks as they make payments for each other's customers. EURO1<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ebaclearing.eu/services/euro1/overview/|title=EURO1|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ebaclearing.eu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref> is owned and operated by EBA Clearing. It is open to banks that have a registered address or branch in the [[European Union]] and fulfil a number of additional requirements. EURO1 is subject to German law (current account principle/single obligation structure) and is based on a messaging and IT infrastructure provided by [[SWIFT]].
=== STEP1 === Since 2000, EBA Clearing has been offering a payment service named STEP1<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ebaclearing.eu/services/step1/overview/ |title=STEP1|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ebaclearing.eu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref> for small and medium-sized banks for single euro payments of high priority and urgency. The technical infrastructure is the same as that of the EURO1 system, both use the messaging and IT infrastructure of SWIFT.
=== STEP2 === STEP2 was put into operation in 2003 with Italian [[payment system]] provider [[SIA S.p.A.]] It processes mass payments in [[euro]]. STEP2 is a [[pan-European automated clearing house]] (PE-ACH).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ebaclearing.eu/services/step2-t-platform/overview/|title=STEP2-T Platform|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ebaclearing.eu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref> This means that it complies with the principles set by the [[European Payments Council]] (EPC) for a PE-ACH Compliant Clearing and Settlement System.
From the beginning of [[Single Euro Payments Area]] (SEPA) on 28 January 2008, STEP2 has been offering SEPA Credit Transfer processing services across all SEPA countries through its SEPA Credit Transfer (SCT) Service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ebaclearing.eu/services/step2-sct/overview/|title=SEPA Credit Transfer (SCT) Service|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ebaclearing.eu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref>
Since 2 November 2009, the transposition date of the [[Payment Services Directive]], EBA Clearing has been processing SEPA Direct Debits with its STEP2 SDD Core<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ebaclearing.eu/services/step2-sdd-core/overview/|title=STEP2 SDD Core Service|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ebaclearing.eu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref> and STEP2 [[SEPA Direct Debit]] ("[[Business-to-business|Business to Business]]")<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ebaclearing.eu/services/step2-sdd-b2b/overview/|title=SEPA Direct Debit ("Business to Business") Service|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ebaclearing.eu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref> Services.
Through its SEPA Credit Transfer and Direct Debit offerings, STEP2 provides banks across Europe with one channel through which they can send and receive their SEPA Credit Transfers and SEPA Direct Debits.<ref>{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Golden |date=April 23, 2015 |url=https://www.euromoney.com/article/b1321vvm42d0lg/cash-management-debate-sepa-a-new-model-for-europe |title=Cash management debate: SEPA: A new model for Europe?|website=Euromoney}}</ref> The STEP2 platform reaches nearly 100 percent of all banks that have signed the SCT and SDD Scheme Adherence Agreements of the [[European Payments Council]] (EPC).
=== MyBank === MyBank is a pan-European e-authorisation solution for online payments that was launched in March 2013 by EBA Clearing. The solution enables customers across Europe to pay for their online purchases via their regular online or mobile banking environment without having to disclose confidential data to the merchant or other third parties. The solution can be used for authorising SEPA Credit Transfers as well as the creation of SDD mandates. At a later stage, MyBank may also be used for transactions in currencies other than euro or for e-identity services.
Today, MyBank is owned and managed by PRETA S.A.S., a wholly owned subsidiary of EBA Clearing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mybank.eu/mybank/preta-sas/|title=PRETA Sas - MyBank|website=www.mybank.eu|access-date=2017-01-06}}</ref>
=== RT1 === RT1 is an [[instant payment]] system that will provide the European payments industry with a pan-European infrastructure platform for real-time payments in euro from day one of the SEPA Instant Credit Transfer Scheme. From 21 November 2017, the RT1 fast payment system will begin operations, allowing commercial banks to offer fast payments through this system to their customers throughout the Eurozone.<ref>{{cite news |first=Yuri |last=Kantsans |url=http://baltnews.lv/news/20171028/1021274777.html |title=Банк Латвии готовится к введению молниеносных платежей в европейском масштабе |trans-title=The Bank of Latvia is preparing to introduce lightning-fast payments on a European scale |date=28 October 2017 |publisher=[[Baltnews|baltnews.lv]]}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{url |http://www.ebaclearing.eu/}} * [https://www.abe-eba.eu www.abe-eba.eu] * [https://www.mybank.eu www.mybank.eu] * [https://www.preta.eu www.preta.eu]
[[Category:Banking in the European Union]] [[Category:Business and finance professional associations]]

{{Infobox person | name = Ellie Kemper | image = Ellie Kemper at the 38th People's Choice Award (cropped).jpg | caption = Kemper in 2012 | alt = Kemper smiling | birth_name = Elizabeth Claire Kemper | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|05|2}} | birth_place = [[Kansas City, Missouri]], U.S. | residence = [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | education = [[Princeton University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[University of Oxford]] {{small|([[Master of Arts|MA]])}} | occupation = Actress, comedian | years_active = 2006–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Michael Koman]]|July 7, 2012}} | children = 1 | relatives = [[Carrie Kemper]] {{Small|(sister)}}
[[William Thornton Kemper Sr.]] {{Small|(great-great-grandfather)}} }} '''Elizabeth Claire Kemper''' (born May 2, 1980{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/ellie-kemper/298647/ |title=Ellie Kemper |publisher=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]] |accessdate=April 14, 2016 |archivedate=March 14, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314120946/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/ellie-kemper/298647/ |deadurl=no}}) is an American actress and comedienne. She played the receptionist [[Erin Hannon]] in the NBC comedy series ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]'' (2009–2013) and later the starring role in the [[Netflix]] comedy series ''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]'' (2015–present), for which she has received two nominations for the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]]. Kemper also appeared in the films ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' (2011) and ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'' (2012). In 2018 she published her first book, ''[[My Squirrel Days]]''.{{cite web |url= https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/ellie-kemper-book-review-my-squirrel-days-1202983066/|title= Ellie Kemper’s Irreverent New Book Tracks Her Missteps and Misadventures in Hollywood|last=Chan |first= Tim|date= 20 October 2018|website=variety.com |publisher=Variety Magazine |access-date=2 November 2018 |quote=}} ==Early life== Kemper was born in [[Kansas City, Missouri]], the second of four children of Dorothy "Dotty" Ann Jannarone and David Woods Kemper, a son of one of the wealthiest families in Missouri.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/09/07/archives/bridal-for-dorothy-a-jannarone.html |work=The New York Times |title=Bridal for Dorothy A. Jannarone |date=September 7, 1975}} Her father was the chairman and chief executive officer of what is today [[Commerce Bancshares]], a [[bank holding company]] founded by the Kemper family. She is the granddaughter of Mildred Lane Kemper, namesake of the [[Mildred Lane Kemper Art Museum]] at [[Washington University in St. Louis]], and great-great-granddaughter of banker, insurance man, and railroad magnate [[William Thornton Kemper Sr.]] She is the older sister of television writer [[Carrie Kemper]]. Kemper has Italian (from her maternal grandfather), English, French (Kemper is the Breton name of the city [[Quimper]]) and German ancestry.{{cite web|title=Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson|work=[[YouTube]]|date=January 26, 2011|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VcFjnCoRa3U|accessdate=April 5, 2011}} Kemper was raised{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2014/12/ellie-kemper-unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt|work=Vanity Fair|title=Profile: Ellie Kemper, Star of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt|author=Steinfeld, Curtis|date=December 10, 2014|accessdate=April 20, 2017}} and remains{{cite web |last=O'Hare |first=Kate |url=http://blog.familytheater.org/ellie-kemper-of-the-unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt-talks-being-catholic-with-stephen-colbert/ |title=Ellie Kemper of ‘The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’ Talks Being Catholic With Stephen Colbert |work=[[Family Theater Productions]] |date=July 12, 2016 |accessdate=January 3, 2016}} a practicing [[Catholic Church in the United States|Roman Catholic]]. Her family moved to [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]] when Kemper was five years old. She attended Conway Elementary School in the affluent suburb of [[Ladue, Missouri|Ladue]] and high school at [[John Burroughs School]], where she developed an interest in theater and improvisational comedy. One of her teachers was actor [[Jon Hamm]], with whom she appeared in a school play. In 1999, Kemper made her [[debutante|debut]] at the [[Veiled Prophet Ball]], where she was named the Veiled Prophet Queen of Love and Beauty.{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/from-vp-queen-to-the-office-john-burroughs-graduate-joins/article_978bc3fd-852f-5d9e-b114-489bb627d8b2.html|title=From VP queen ...to 'The Office'; John Burroughs graduate joins fellow St. Louisans Jenna Fischer and Phyllis Smith at Dunder Mifflin|date=December 13, 2009|work=stltoday.com}} Kemper graduated from [[Princeton University]] in 2002 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in English.{{Cite news|last=Pennington|first=Gail|title=From VP queen ...to 'The Office'|work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|date=December 13, 2009|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/article_978bc3fd-852f-5d9e-b114-489bb627d8b2.html|accessdate=December 16, 2010}} At Princeton, Kemper was a member of the school's improv comedy troupe, Quipfire. She played on the school's 1998 [[NCAA Women's Field Hockey Championship|national championship]] [[field hockey]] team,{{cite web |title=1999 Preseason Women's Field Hockey Roster|url=http://www.fansonly.com/schools/prin/sports/w-fieldh/mtt/prin-w-fieldh-mtt.html|publisher=FansOnly.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000310143533/http://www.fansonly.com/schools/prin/sports/w-fieldh/mtt/prin-w-fieldh-mtt.html|archivedate=March 10, 2000}} maintaining she sat on the bench "roughly 97 percent" of the time{{Cite news|last=Tomlinson|first=Brett|title=Office Addition|work=[[Princeton Alumni Weekly]]|url=http://blogs.princeton.edu/paw/2009/04/office_addition.html|date=April 15, 2009|accessdate=May 23, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429033423/http://blogs.princeton.edu/paw/2009/04/office_addition.html |archivedate=April 29, 2009}} before moving on the following year to focus on theatre. She attended the [[University of Oxford]], where she studied at [[Worcester College]] towards a graduate degree in English.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bucknell.edu/news-and-media/events-and-calendars/2016/ellie-kemper-star-of-unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt-and-the-office-to-speak-at-bucknell.html|title=Ellie Kemper, Star of Unbreakable Kimmu Schmidt and The Office, to Speak at Bucknell|website=Bucknell.edu|access-date=January 26, 2017}} ==Career== {{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 | salign=center | width=195px |align=right | quote = I'm the most comfortable when I'm playing a naturalistic character. I auditioned for ''Saturday Night Live'', and when I was doing the biggest characters, I felt the least comfortable. I'm just more comfortable when it's some version of myself. | source = Ellie Kemper}} Kemper continued her interest in improvisational comedy while at Princeton. Kemper participated in Quipfire!, Princeton's oldest improv comedy group,{{cite web |title=About – Quipfire! |url=http://quipfireimprov.com/about/ |publisher=Quipfire |accessdate=May 10, 2016}} and the [[Princeton Triangle Club]], a touring musical comedy theater troupe. She also appeared in a radio spot for [[Dunkin' Donuts]]. Kemper earned her [[Screen Actors Guild]] card doing commercial advertising of a one-week sale of tents at [[Kmart]].Moynihan, Rob (January 18, 2016). "How I Got My SAG-AFTRA Card", ''[[TV Guide]]''. p. 12. The commercial featured her camping with an onscreen husband, and a shot in which a [[tarantula]] crawls across her face.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rbH7hsyzT2E She regularly appeared in comedy sketches on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' in the late 2000s, and has made guest appearances on ''[[Important Things with Demetri Martin]]'', and [[E!]] Television's ''[[The Gastineau Girls]]'',{{cite web |title=Ellie Kemper |work=[[Upright Citizens Brigade]] |url=http://www.ucbcomedy.com/user/2983 |accessdate=March 14, 2015}}{{cite web |title=Biographies |work=How to Kick People: About this Show |url=http://www.howtokickpeople.com/bios.html |accessdate=March 22, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090526170059/http://howtokickpeople.com/bios.html |archive-date=2009-05-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} which has been described as her "breakout role". She has appeared on [[Fuse TV]]'s ''The P.A.'' In October 2008, Kemper appeared on ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' in a PSA for Teen Voter Abstinence.{{cite web |title=Colbert Report |work=Colbert Teen Talk |url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/186530/october-01-2008/colbert-teen-talk---voter-abstinence |accessdate=September 9, 2009}} Kemper has written several [[sketch comedy]] shows{{cite web |title=Ellie Kemper |work=The PIT |url=http://www.jesterjournal.com/ScottEllie2.htm |accessdate=April 15, 2006}} many of them with her comedy partner Scott Eckert, a fellow Princeton grad. Kemper is a contributing writer for the national satirical newspaper ''[[The Onion]]'',{{cite web |title=Contact The Onion |work=[[The Onion]]}} and for ''[[McSweeney's]]''.{{cite web |last=Kemper |first=Ellie |title=Listen, Kid, The Biggest Thing You've Got Going For You Is Your Rack |work=McSweeney's |date=December 14, 2005 |url=http://www.mcsweeneys.net/2005/12/14kemper.html |accessdate=May 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526024350/http://www.mcsweeneys.net/2005/12/14kemper.html |archivedate=May 26, 2011 |df=mdy}}{{cite web |last=Kemper |first=Ellie |title=Following My Creative Writing Teacher's Advice To Write 'Like My Parents Are Dead' |date=October 23, 2006 |url=http://www.mcsweeneys.net/2006/10/23kemper.html |work=McSweeney's |accessdate=November 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091225064340/http://www.mcsweeneys.net/2006/10/23kemper.html |archivedate=December 25, 2009 |df=mdy}}{{cite web |last=Kemper |first=Ellie |title=Some Relatively Recent College Grads Discuss Their Maids |date=December 13, 2007 |work=McSweeney's |url=http://www.mcsweeneys.net/2007/12/13kemper.html |accessdate=November 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091225100412/http://www.mcsweeneys.net/2007/12/13kemper.html |archivedate=December 25, 2009 |df=mdy}} She is also a contributor to ''[[The Huffington Post]]''.{{Cite news |title=Huffington Post Bloggers |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ellie-kemper |accessdate=May 5, 2010 |first=Ellie |last=Kemper}}{{Cite news |last=Kemper |first=Ellie |title=I'm Not Exactly Afraid of Really Intense Fashion |date=December 2, 2009 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ellie-kemper/im-not-exactly-afraid-of_b_374506.html |accessdate=May 5, 2010 |work=The Huffington Post}} [[File:Ellie Kemper UCB cropped.jpg|thumb|Kemper performing "Feeling Sad/Mad with Ellie Kemper" at the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theater]] in 2008]] Upon moving to New York City, Kemper participated in the People's Improv Theatre and the city troupe of [[Upright Citizens Brigade]], an improvisational comedy and sketch comedy theater. She has appeared in several shows for the Brigade, including ''Death and/or Despair'', ''Listen Kid'', ''Gang Bang'' and ''The Improvised Mystery''. At the UCB, she performed with the house improv teams Mailer Daemon and fwand. At the People's Improv Theatre she performs with the house improv team Big Black Car.{{cite web|title=Ellie Kemper |work=The PIT |url=http://www.thepit-nyc.com/performers/ekemper.html |accessdate=September 9, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906112132/http://thepit-nyc.com/performers/ekemper.html |archivedate=September 6, 2009 |df=mdy }} In August 2008, she auditioned for a spot on the NBC sketch comedy show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', but was not cast.{{Cite news |title=10 Comics to Watch: Ellie Kemper |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=July 17, 2009 |last=Hensley |first=Dennis |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118006156.html?categoryid=3183&cs=1 |accessdate=September 6, 2009}} In July 2009, Kemper was named one of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine's "10 Comics To Watch". {{Quote box |quoted=true |salign=center | width=195px |align=left | quote = Being on set with them is like being in a dream, except the dream is real and I can reach out and touch them. Except I am trying not to touch them too much, because I was raised right. | source = Ellie Kemper on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]''}} In 2007, she appeared in ''How to Kick People'', a performance combining comedy and literary performances. In March 2008, she wrote and performed in the one-woman show "Dumb Girls" through the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]]. She also performed in the one-woman show "Feeling Sad/Mad with Ellie Kemper" and has appeared in comedy sketches on [[Funny or Die]], the comedy website started by [[Will Ferrell]] and [[Adam McKay]]'s production company, [[Gary Sanchez Productions]].{{Cite news|last=Cain |first=Brooke |work=[[The News & Observer]] |title=New receptionist on 'The Office' |date=March 21, 2009 |url=http://blogs.newsobserver.com/category/tags/Ellie-Kemper |accessdate=March 22, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417061013/http://blogs.newsobserver.com/category/tags/Ellie-Kemper |archivedate=April 17, 2009 |df=mdy }} Kemper gained some [[List of Internet phenomena|Internet fame]] in August 2007 for her part in "Blowjob Girl", a humor video on the sketch comedy site [[Derrick Comedy]]. The video, which was circulated on the popular site [[CollegeHumor]], was a two-minute close-up of Kemper offering to perform [[oral sex]] on her boyfriend, but startling him by promising to bite and smash his genitals, which she seems to believe is arousing.{{cite web |title=I'm Gonna Make it Sooo Dry For You... |work=AmFmPm |date=May 7, 2007 |url=http://www.amfmpm.org/2007/07/blowjobs-blowjob-right.html |accessdate=June 1, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924031130/http://www.amfmpm.org/2007/07/blowjobs-blowjob-right.html |archive-date=2009-09-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Kemper said of the video in an April 2010 interview with ''[[The A.V. Club]]'': "I really don't like that video, and I wish that I hadn't done it, even though I know that it's a joke. I hate that it got sort of big, because I don't think that it's that funny and I don't want that to be the epitome of my work. It's just one video in a sea of many, but it has made me conscious of not wanting to do a video like that again."{{cite web |title=Ellie Kemper Interview |work=The A.V. Club |date=April 20, 2010 |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/ellie-kemper,40258/ |accessdate=May 6, 2010}} Kemper has also contributed an article to [[CollegeHumor]] entitled "Regarding Our Decision Never to See Me Again".{{cite web|title=Regarding Our Decision Never to See Me Again |work=[[CollegeHumor]] |date=February 1, 2007 |url=http://www.collegehumor.com/article:1717592 |accessdate=May 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012121854/http://www.collegehumor.com/article%3A1717592 |archivedate=October 12, 2009 |df=mdy }} She also had a minor role in the 2009 film ''[[Mystery Team]]''. Kemper starred in a fake [[iPhone]] commercial on ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien'' in January 2007, six months before the first iPhone was released.{{Cite news|title=Last Night's Episode |work=NBC Message Boards |url=http://boards.nbc.com/nbc/index.php?showtopic=718874&st=1260 |accessdate=September 9, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070913141427/http://boards.nbc.com/nbc/index.php?showtopic=718874 |archivedate=September 13, 2007 |df=mdy }} Kemper appeared in the [[Sofia Coppola]] comedy-drama ''[[Somewhere (film)|Somewhere]]'' in 2010. She appeared in ''[[Bridesmaids (2011 film)|Bridesmaids]]'' in 2011.{{cite web |title=Ellie Kemper |publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2608689/ |accessdate=May 5, 2010}} On April 3, 2013, it was announced that Kemper would be [[voice acting|voicing]] a character in an episode of the [[animated sitcom]] ''[[American Dad!]]''.{{cite web |last=Masters |first=Megan |url=http://tvline.com/2013/04/03/american-dad-cast-ellie-kemper-voice-popular-girl/ |title=''American Dad'' Cast – Ellie Kemper to Voice Popular Girl |publisher=TVLine |date=March 29, 2013 |accessdate=April 4, 2013}} [[File:Ellie Kemper photo by Josephine Sittenfeld.jpg|thumb|left|Ellie Kemper in 2002]] Kemper auditioned for a role in ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'', an [[NBC]] comedy series started in 2009 by [[Michael Schur]] and [[Greg Daniels]], creator of the series ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]''. She was not cast in the role, but received a call back to audition for a supporting role in ''The Office'' as [[Erin Hannon]], a secretary filling in for the regular secretary [[Pam Beesly]] when she briefly left the job at the end of the [[The Office (US TV series) season 5|fifth season]]. Kemper was cast in the role, and started appearing in the show in April 2009. The character was originally written to be more sarcastic and dry, but the writers changed her to be more perky and optimistic to more closely resemble Kemper herself. Kemper described the character as "an exaggerated version of myself". Kemper described herself as a "huge fan" of the show and was thrilled to be on it. Although the character was originally intended for four episodes, the producers were impressed with Kemper and signed her as a regular in the [[The Office (US TV series) season 6|sixth season]]. [[Jennifer Celotta]], a screenwriter with the series, described Kemper as a "fun addition" to the show.{{Cite news |title="Company Picnic" Q&A with Jen Celotta |work=OfficeTally |url=http://www.officetally.com/company-picnic-qa-with-jen-celotta |date=May 22, 2009 |accessdate=May 23, 2009}} Kemper received positive reviews for her role in ''The Office''. Alan Sepinwall, television columnist with ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'', praised the "infectious joy and sweetness" she brought to the show. Joshua Ostroff of ''[[Eye Weekly]]'' described Erin as one of the best new television characters of the 2008–2009 season and said, "Erin's high-grade adorability, up-for-anything attitude and sheer niceness is unlike anyone else in the office, adding a welcome new wrinkle for next season."{{Cite news |last=Ostroff |first=Joshua |title=Leaders of the New School: Great performances in the margins brought a so-so season to life |date=May 20, 2009 |work=[[Eye Weekly]] |url=http://www.eyeweekly.com/film/tv/article/60934--leaders-of-the-new-school |accessdate=May 23, 2009}}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Andy Shaw of ''TV Fodder'' said she "adds some freshness to the cast"{{Cite news |last=Shaw |first=Andy |title=The Office: "Cafe Disco" |work=TV Fodder |date=May 7, 2009 |url=http://www.tvfodder.com/office/archives/2009/05/cafe_disco.shtml |accessdate=May 8, 2009}} and Josh McAuliffe of ''[[The Times-Tribune (Scranton)|The Times-Tribune]]'' in [[Scranton, Pennsylvania|Scranton]], Pennsylvania, said he liked Erin's "cheerful, appealingly goofy personality".{{Cite news |last=McAuliffe |first=Josh |title="Cafe Disco" Recap |work=[[The Times-Tribune (Scranton)|The Times-Tribune]] |location=[[Scranton, Pennsylvania|Scranton]], Pennsylvania |date=May 8, 2009 |url=http://community.thetimes-tribune.com/blogs/theoffice/archive/2009/05/08/quot-cafe-disco-quot-recap.aspx |accessdate=May 8, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Many critics have singled her out as a highlight of the show's [[The Office (U.S. season 8)|eighth season]] following [[Steve Carell]]'s departure.{{cite web |last=Myles |first=McNutt |title=Tallahassee |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/tallahassee,69358/ |work=The A.V. Club |date=February 16, 2012 |accessdate=February 17, 2012}}{{cite web |last=Hertz |first=Barry |url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/10/28/recap-the-office-season-8-episode-5/ |title=The Office, Season 8, Episode 5: Recap |work=[[National Post]] |date=October 28, 2011 |accessdate=October 29, 2011 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130104055904/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/10/28/recap-the-office-season-8-episode-5/ |archive-date=2013-01-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{cite web |last=McNutt |first=Myles |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/spooked,63910/ |title=Spooked |work=The A.V. Club |date=October 27, 2011 |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}{{cite web |last=McNutt |first=Myles |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/christmas-wishes,66272/ |title=Christmas Wishes |work=The A.V. Club |date=December 8, 2011 |accessdate=December 8, 2011}}{{cite web |last=Mader |first=Jill |title=The Office – Episode 8–12 Review – "A Party to Remember" |url=http://insidepulse.com/2012/01/20/the-office-episode-8-12-review-a-party-to-remember/ |publisher=InsidePulse |accessdate=February 17, 2012}}{{cite web |last=Tedder |first=Michael |url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2012/02/office-recap-season-8-episode-14.html |title=The Office Recap: Florida Facts |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=February 10, 2012 |accessdate=February 10, 2012}} In October 2009, Kemper appeared in ''[[Subtle Sexuality]]'', a set of three ''The Office'' webisodes about efforts by Erin and [[Kelly Kapoor]] ([[Mindy Kaling]]) to start a [[girl group]]. She stars in the [[Netflix]] original comedy series ''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]'' as the fish-out-of-water [[Kimmy Schmidt|title character]]. She plays a former abductee and forced cult-member who wants to shed the victim pity of her small hometown and moves to New York.Michael Martin, [http://www.out.com/television/2015/3/03/tituss-burgess "Why Tituss Burgess Makes Tina Fey Laugh"], ''Out'', March 4, 2015. Her performance on the show has been widely acclaimed, and she received multiple nominations for the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild Award]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/05/allison-williams-face-calms-ellie-kempers-baby.html|title=Allison Williams’s Face Is the Only Thing That Calms Ellie Kemper’s Baby|last=McHenry|first=Jackson|work=Vulture|access-date=May 26, 2017}} and [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]]. In the summer of 2015, Kemper served as a temporary co-host of ''[[The Today Show]]'' alongside [[Al Roker]], [[Natalie Morales (journalist)|Natalie Morales]], [[Tamron Hall]], and [[Willie Geist]].Will Lerner, [https://www.yahoo.com/tv/today-has-a-lot-of-hosts-matt-lauer-savannah-122435491680.html "'Today' Announces Ellie Kemper as New Co-Host"], Yahoo TV, June 25, 2015. In 2018, Kemper was one of the actors who voiced the audiobook ''[[A Day in the Life of Marlon Bundo]]''.{{cite news |last=Perkins |first=Dennis |date=March 19, 2018 |title=John Oliver hijacks homophobe Mike Pence's bunny book with a better one in A Day In The Life Of Marlon Bundo |url=https://www.avclub.com/john-oliver-hijacks-homophobe-mike-pences-bunny-book-wi-1823879129 |work=AV Club |location= |access-date=March 19, 2018 }} In 2018 she also published her first book, entitled ''My Squirrel Days''. ==Personal life== In 2012, Kemper became engaged to boyfriend [[Michael Koman]], a writer whose credits include ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' and ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]''.{{cite news |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/the-office-star-ellie-kemper-is-engaged-2011812 |title=The Office Star Ellie Kemper Is Engaged! |author=Zach Johnson |date=December 8, 2011 |work=[[Us Weekly]] |accessdate=May 22, 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/offices-ellie-kemper-announces-engagement-271945 |title=The actress' fiance, Michael Koman, is a former "Late Night with Conan O'Brien" and "The Colbert Report" writer. |author=Lauren Schutte |date=December 9, 2011 |accessdate=May 22, 2012 |work=The Hollywood Reporter}} The couple married on July 7, 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20610212,00.html |title=Ellie Kemper Is Married! |author=Alison Schwartz |work=People |date=July 7, 2012 |accessdate=July 8, 2012}} Kemper has a son, James, who was born in 2016.{{cite web|last=Respers |first=Lisa |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/02/entertainment/ellie-kemper-baby/ |title='Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt' star Ellie Kemper gives birth |website=CNN.com |date=August 2, 2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}} On ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]'', Kemper stated that she hopes to raise her son [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]].{{Cite news|url=http://blog.familytheater.org/ellie-kemper-of-the-unbreakable-kimmy-schmidt-talks-being-catholic-with-stephen-colbert/|title=Ellie Kemper of ‘The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’ Talks Being Catholic With Stephen Colbert|work=Faith & Family Media Blog|access-date=April 23, 2018}} ==Filmography== ===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox person | name =Eric Kinoti | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1984|3|8}} | birth_place =[[Mombasa]], [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Industrialist]], [[Entrepreneur]] shade systems EA.ltd | years_active = 2009–present | nationality = Kenyan | citizenship = {{KEN}} | residence = [[Nairobi]] | known_for = Business, Philanthropy | networth = | home_town = [[Nairobi]] | title = [[CEO]] and [[Entrepreneurship|founder]] Shadesystems | website = {{URL|www.erickinoti.com}} }}
'''Eric Kinoti''' is a [[Kenyan]] [[entrepreneur]] of African descent born in [[Mombasa]] on 8 March 1984.<ref name="citizen">{{cite news| title=Business Center Interview with Eric Kinoti, CEO Shade System |date=29 October 2014| url=http://citizentv.co.ke/news/business-center-interview-with-eric-kinoti-ceo-ae-shade-system/}}</ref> Along with being the Founder and CEO of Shade systems EA.ltd, a million dollar enterprise that has a presence in over 6 countries,<ref name="CORPORATE NEWS">{{cite news| title=From a shoestring start-up to leading supplier of tents| date=16 August 2015| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/From-a-shoestring-start-up-to-leading-supplier-of-tents-/-/539550/1751260/-/3goojfz/-/index.html}}</ref> he is on the boards of several prominent East African companies. He has won several awards in East Africa and internationally, has gained recognition for his entrepreneurial endeavors, and is also a noted philanthropist.
He is the Kenyan youth [[patron]] in the Kenyan [[Chamber of commerce]] and has received recognition as a youth entrepreneur from Kenyan president [[Uhuru Kenyatta]].<ref name="entrepreneur">{{cite news| title=ERIC KINOTI: YOUNG KENYAN ENTREPRENEUR TO WATCH| date=7 January 2015| url=http://www.africanpro.co.za/entrepreneurs/item/626-eric-kinoti-young-kenyan-entrepreneur-to-watch}}</ref> Apart from appearing on [[Forbes|''Forbes Africa{{'}}''s Annual List of 30 Most Promising Young Entrepreneurs in Africa]] twice,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2015/02/05/30-most-promising-young-entrepreneurs-in-africa-2015/#4906b27d23f0|title=30 Most Promising Young Entrepreneurs In Africa 2015|last=Nsehe|first=Mfonobong|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2014/02/04/30-most-promising-young-entrepreneurs-in-africa-2014|title=30 Most Promising Young Entrepreneurs In Africa 2014|first=Mfonobong|last=Nsehe|publisher=}}</ref> he received [http://soma.or.ke/ Kenya's SOMA Awards] in 2014 for being the Most Influential SME Personality in Kenya in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://classic105.com/olx-soma-awards-2014/|title=Here's the full list of winners from the 2014 SOMA awards - Classic 105|date=2014-10-04|work=Classic 105|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Early life== After [[college]] Kinoti worked as a cashier in a hotel in [[Malindi]] and that's where his entrepreneurial journey truly began. Since he worked in the night shift,Kinoti spent his day time buying and distributing eggs around [[Malindi]] town. A few years later, he moved to Nairobi where he distributed milk to hotels in the city.<ref name="entrepreneur"/> Kinoti, grew up in [[Meru, Kenya|Meru]], where he assisted his father in the shop as a cashier after school. Kinoti has conceded that, "I started Shade System Company aged 24 with only five employees and a seed capital of Sh60,000. I saw a business gap because this sector was predominantly controlled by non-Kenyans an attestation to his humble beginnings. However, his father, a shop owner, was determined on giving the young Kinoti the best [[education]] available.
==Education== Kinoti attended St. Martins Boarding Primary School, Abothogochi Academy, Nkubu High School and earned a Diploma in [[Business Management]] from Tsavo Park Institute.<ref name="entrepreneur"/>
==Business== Eric Kinoti immersed himself into entrepreneurism completely in 2007. With a capital of just KSh 20,000 (about $200), he started buying milk from Kinoo and [[Kiambu]] and supplying the city hotels both in [[Nairobi]] and [[Mombasa]].<ref name="companies">{{cite news| title= Eric Kinoti eLearning:Entrepreneurship – How to start small and how to manage growth | date=1 September 2015| url=http://erickinoti.com}}</ref> With a saving of Ksh 60,000(US$600), he borrowed almost KSh2 million (US$20,000) from a [[Shylock]] in 2009, to set up Shade Systems where he ended up paying back the money with a million shillings (US$10,000) as the [[interest]]. He claims that was the worst decision he has ever made. <ref>{{cite news| title= Shade Systems entrepreneur Eric Kinoti; I make millions but I'm not a millionaire...yet | date=8 November 2014| url= http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/evewoman/m/article/2000140749/shade-systems-entrepreneur-eric-kinoti-i-make-millions-but-i-m-not-a-millionaire-yet?articleID=2000140749&story_title=shade-systems-entrepreneur-eric-kinoti-i-make-millions-but-i-m-not-a-millionaire-yet&pageNo=2}}</ref>
Today, Kinoti sits atop five powerful companies in Kenya and has been on Kenya's [[government]] [[delegation]] to several international economic meetings.<ref name="man">{{cite news|title=Think big, start small |date=22 February 2015 |url=http://sunnewsonline.com/new/think-big-start-small |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150802003039/http://sunnewsonline.com/new/think-big-start-small/ |archivedate=2015-08-02 |df= }}</ref> Apart from Shade systems (EA) ltd,Eric Kinoti is also a founder and director of Alma Tents Ltd, Bag Base Kenya Ltd and SafiSana Home Services Ltd.<ref name="companies"/> With the onset of the 2009 and 2014 came the expansion of Shade Systems to other countries such as [[Rwanda]], [[Somalia]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]], [[Southern Sudan]], [[Uganda]] and elsewhere with Kinoti being charged with business affairs in [[East]] and [[Central Africa]] region.
Kinoti has been regarded as the Warren Buffett of Africa by the sun news <ref name= "man"/>
==Philanthropy== Having gone through hard times and a lot of challenges, Kinoti's desire and dream is to [[motivate]] and [[mentor]] young entrepreneurs and start-ups to break through. He has been organizing [[workshops]] for young entrepreneurs across Africa named Entrepreneurs' Boot Camp with speakers from all parts of [[Africa]].<ref name="philanthropy">{{cite news| title=TwendeMara Boot Camp is Finally Here| date=19 December 2014| url=http://www.entrepreneursbootcamp.net| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907173545/http://www.entrepreneursbootcamp.net/| archivedate=7 September 2015| df=}}</ref>
==Personal life== Eric Kinoti is married to a wife with whom he has one child.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/evewoman/article/2000140749/shade-systems-entrepreneur-eric-kinoti-i-make-millions-but-i-m-not-a-millionaire-yet|title=Shade Systems entrepreneur Eric Kinoti;I make millions but I'm not a millionaire...yet|last=Oduor|first=Peter|date=2014-11-08|work=Evewoman - Woman's World|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en-US}}</ref> He lives in Westlands [[suburb]] of Nairobi, Kenya.
==See also== *[[List of African millionaires]] *[[List of wealthiest people in Kenya]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150907173545/http://www.entrepreneursbootcamp.net/]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kinoti, Eric}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kenyan people of African descent]] [[Category:Kenyan philanthropists]]
