'''Skid Row''' is an area of [[Downtown Los Angeles]]. As of the 2000 census, the population of the district was 17,740.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} Skid Row was defined in a decision in ''Jones v. City of Los Angeles'' as the area east of Main Street, south of Third Street, west of Alameda Street, and north of Seventh Street.<ref>[https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-9th-circuit/1490887.html "Jones v. City of Los Angeles"] on [[Findlaw.com]]</ref> Skid Row contains one of the largest stable populations (between 5,000 and 8,000) of [[homeless people in the United States]].<ref>John Edwin Fuder, ''Training Students for Urban Ministry: An Experiential Approach.'' Eugene, OR: Wipf & Stock (2001).</ref>
==Etymology== The term "[[skid row]]" or "skid road", referring to an area of a city where people live who are "on the skids", derives from a logging term. Loggers would transport their logs to a nearby river by sliding them down roads made from greased skids. Loggers who had accompanied the load to the bottom of the road would wait there for transportation back up the hill to the logging camp. By extension, the term began to be used for places where people with no money and nothing to do gathered, becoming the generic term for a depressed street in a city.<ref>[[Eric Partridge|Partridge, Eric]]; Beale, Paul (ed.) ''A Concise Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English'' New York< Macmillam (1989). p.405</ref>
==History== [[File:Steam locomotive in front of the Los Angeles and Independence Rail Road Terminal at Fifth Street and San Pedro Street, Los Angeles, 1875 (CHS-14279).jpg|thumb|250px|left|The corner of 5th and San Pedro in 1875]]
{{quote box|quote=The population is probably more motley than that in a similar district of any other American city. Jews, Greeks, and Italians in the doorways of pawnshops and secondhand clothing stores vie with one another to lure the unwary passer-by inside. A fat German runs a beer parlor and just across the street a dapper Frenchman ladles up 5-cent bowls of split pea soup. A large, blond woman named Sunshine, born in Egypt, manages one of the cleaner rooming houses. A few Chinese practically monopolize the hand laundry business, and Japanese the cheapest cafes and flophouses. Americans Indians barter for forbidden whiskey. Chattering Mexicans loiter on the steps leading up to a second-floor hotel. Dapper Negroes, better dressed than any other vagabonds, wander by in riotous groups.|source=Huston Irvine, ''Los Angeles Times'' (March 26, 1939)<ref name=serenade/>| bgcolor = Cornsilk| font = Times|width=28%|align=right|title=Skidrow Serenade}}
===1880s through 1960s=== At the end of the 19th century, a number of residential hotels opened in the area as it became home to a transient population of seasonal laborers.<ref name="resource1">{{cite web |url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F3/444/444.F3d.1118.04-55324.html |title=444 F.3d 1118 |publisher=Bulk.resource.org |accessdate=2013-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100517210145/http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F3/444/444.F3d.1118.04-55324.html |archivedate=2010-05-17 |df= }}</ref> By the 1930s, Skid Row was home to as many as 10,000 homeless people, alcoholics, and others on the margins of society.<ref name=serenade>{{cite news |last=Irvine |first=Huston |date=March 26, 1939 |title=Skid Row Serenade |work=Los Angeles Times |page=I6}}</ref> It supported saloons, residential hotels, and social services, which drew people from the populations they served to congregate in the area.<ref name="Wild2008">{{cite book |last=Wild |first=Mark |date=2 June 2008 |title=Street Meeting: Multiethnic Neighborhoods in Early Twentieth-century Los Angeles |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-94176-2 |page=152 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b_CekfFgglkC&pg=PA152 |accessdate=25 May 2013}}</ref>
In June 1947, LAPD chief [[Clemence B. Horrall]] ordered what he called a "blockade raid" of the whole Skid Row area. Over 350 people were arrested. Assistant Chief Joseph Reed, who claimed that "at least 50 percent of all the crime in Los Angeles originates in the Skid Row area," stated that there had been no "strong arm robberies" on Skid Row as late as one week after the raid. Long time residents, however, were skeptical that the changes would last.<ref name=bowery>{{cite news |last=Boyle |first=Hal |date=June 14, 1947 |title=Skid Row; The West's Bowery |publisher=Evening Independent |page=10 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UswLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GFUDAAAAIBAJ&dq=los-angeles%20skid-row&pg=5989%2C1344783}}</ref>
In 1956, the city of Los Angeles was in the midst of a program to "rehabilitate" Skid Row<ref name=fight/> through the clearance of decaying buildings.<ref name=landlords>{{cite news |last=Sibley |first=John |date=July 3, 1960 |title=Slum Landlords Under Cities' Fire |work=The New York Times |page=1}}</ref> The program was presented to property owners in the area as an economy measure. Gilbert Morris, then superintendent of building, said that at that point the provision of free social services to the approximately one square mile of Skid Row cost the city over $5 million per year as opposed to the city average of $110,000 per square mile annually.<ref name=fight>{{cite news |last=Stern |first=Walter H. |date=June 28, 1956 |title=Wide Fight Urged on Decay in Cities |work=The New York Times |page=48}}</ref> The city used administrative hearings to compel the destruction of nuisance properties at the expense of the owner. By July 1960, the clearance program was said to be 87% complete in the Skid Row area.<ref name=landlords/>
===1970s through present=== {{Update|section|reason=Only goes through 2006|date=June 2018}} In the 1970s, two [[Catholic Worker Movement|Catholic Workers]] — Catherine Morris, a [[List of former Roman Catholic nuns|former nun]], and her husband, Jeff Dietrich — founded the "Hippie Kitchen" in the back of a van. Forty years later, in April 2014, aged 80 and 68, they remained active in their work feeding Skid Row residents.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Streeter | first = Kurt | date = 2014-04-09 | title = A couple's commitment to skid row doesn't waver | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | url = http://www.latimes.com/local/la-me-c1-catholic-workers-20140409-dto,0,4244985.htmlstory | accessdate = 2014-04-09 }}</ref>
====1987 crackdowns==== In February 1987, LAPD chief [[Daryl Gates]], backed by then-Mayor [[Tom Bradley (American politician)|Tom Bradley]], announced plans for another crackdown on the homeless on Skid Row.<ref name=tangle>{{cite news |last1=Boyarsky |first1=Bill |last2=McMillan |first2=Penelope |date=May 30, 1987 |title=L.A. City Attorney, Mayor Tangle Over Police Plan to Jail Homeless |work=Los Angeles Times |page=A13}}</ref> Police and firefighters conducted a number of sweeps through the area but the plan was abandoned due to opposition by advocates for the homeless.<ref name=tangle/>
When Gates announced in May that the crackdown would resume, Los Angeles City Attorney (and future mayor) [[James K. Hahn]] responded that he would not prosecute people arrested in the planned sweeps.<ref name=wont>{{cite news |last1=Boyarsky |first1=Bill |last2=McMillan |first2=Penelope |date=May 30, 1987 |title=Won't Prosecute Homeless Who Are Arrested—Hahn |work=Los Angeles Times |page=1}}</ref> Hahn stated that he was "not going to prosecute individuals for not having a place to stay. I simply will not prosecute people for being poor, underprivileged and unable to find a place to sleep until I'm convinced that a viable alternative to sleeping on the streets exists."<ref name=wont/> Gates, still backed by Bradley, responded: "As the elected city attorney of Los Angeles, Mr. Hahn has a responsibility to file prosecutable cases which are presented to him by the Los Angeles Police Department."<ref name=tangle/>
A few days later, then-Councilman [[Zev Yaroslavsky]] introduced a proposal that the city stop enforcing its anti-camping laws on Skid Row until adequate housing could be found for all its residents.<ref name=zev>{{cite news |last=McMillan |first=Penelope |date=June 3, 1987 |title=L.A. Council Asks Police to Scrap Arrests of Homeless Unless Rooms Are Available |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |edition=Orange County |page=A11}}</ref> The council rejected Yaroslavsky's proposal, but after hearing testimony from Assistant Police Chief David Dotson describing the LAPD's intended crackdown methodology, the council passed a motion asking Gates not to enforce the anti-camping laws until adequate housing could be found for the area's residents.<ref name=zev/>
====Patient dumping==== In September 2005, hospitals and law enforcement agencies were discovered to be "dumping" homeless people on Skid Row. Then-Mayor [[Antonio Villaraigosa]] ordered an investigation and [[William Bratton]], LAPD chief at the time, claimed that the department was not targeting homeless people specifically, but only people who violate city ordinances.<ref name="CookMalone2012">{{cite book |last1=Cook |first1=Joseph G. |last2=Malone |first2=Linda A. |last3=Marcus |first3=Paul |last4=Moohr |first4=Geraldine Szott |date=17 July 2012 |title=Criminal Law |publisher=LexisNexis |isbn=978-1-57911-678-1 |page=63 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zMuiJLbCW2UC&pg=PT63 |accessdate=25 May 2013}}</ref> The [[Los Angeles City Attorney]] investigated more than 50 of about 150 reported cases of dumping.<ref name="Jansson2011">{{cite book |last=Jansson |first=Bruce S. |date=2011 |title=Becoming an Effective Policy Advocate: From Policy Practice to Social Justice |publisher=Cengage Learning |isbn=978-0-495-81239-5 |page=55 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OmkE7Zs91uMC&pg=PA55 |accessdate=25 May 2013}}</ref> By early 2007, the city attorney had filed charges against only one hospital, [[Kaiser Permanente]]. Because there were no laws specifically covering the hospital's actions, it was charged, in an untested strategy, with [[false imprisonment]]. In response to the lack of legal recourse available to fight patient dumping, [[California State Senate|California state senator]] [[Gil Cedillo]] sponsored legislation against it in February 2007.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Winton |first1=Richard |last2=Blankenstein |first22=Andrew |date=February 22, 2007 |title=California bill would ban patient dumping |work=Herald-Journal |page=4 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SgsqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mNAEAAAAIBAJ&dq=los-angeles%20skid-row&pg=6980%2C2769487}}</ref>
====2006 lawsuit==== In 2002, newly appointed [[LAPD]] chief [[William Bratton]] announced a plan to clean up Skid Row by, among other things, aggressively enforcing an old anti-camping ordinance.<ref name=victory/> Robert Lee Purrie, for instance, was cited twice for violating the ordinance in December 2002 and January 2003 and his possessions: "blankets, clothes, cooking utensils, a hygiene kit," and so on, were confiscated by the police.<ref name=victory/>
[[File:MidnightMission.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Midnight Mission on Skid Row]]
In April 2006, [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] ruled in favor of the [[ACLU]] in its suit against the city of Los Angeles, filed on behalf of Purrie and five other homeless people, finding that the city was in violation of the 8th and 14th Amendments to the U.S. Constitution and sections of the California Constitution guaranteeing [[due process]] and [[equal protection]] and prohibiting [[cruel and unusual punishment]].<ref name=victory>{{cite news |last1=Weinstein |first1=Henry |last2=DiMassa |first2=Cara Mia |date=April 15, 2006 |title=Justices Hand L.A.'s Homeless a Victory; In a case with national import, a federal appeals court rules the LAPD cannot arrest people for sitting, lying or sleeping on skid row sidewalks |work=Los Angeles Times |edition=Home |page=A1 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/422101669/9CC70A082C5A48C2PQ/12}}{{paywall}}</ref> The court stated that "the LAPD cannot arrest people for sitting, lying, or sleeping on public sidewalks in Skid Row." The court said that the anti-camping ordinance is "one of the most restrictive municipal laws regulating public spaces in the United States."<ref name=victory/>
The ACLU sought a compromise in which the LAPD would be barred from arresting homeless people or confiscating their possession on Skid Row between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. The compromise plan, which was accepted by the city of Los Angeles, permits sleeping on the sidewalk except "within 10 feet of any business or residential entrance" and only between these hours.<ref name=respite>{{cite news |last=Moore |first=Solomon |date=October 31, 2007 |title=Some Respite, if Little Cheer, for Skid Row Homeless |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/31/us/31skidrow.html |accessdate=May 25, 2013}}</ref>
Downtown development business interests and the Central City East Association (CCEA) came out against the compromise. On September 20, 2006, Los Angeles City Council voted to reject the compromise.<ref>{{cite web |date=2006-09-20 |title=Handing Skid Row to the drug dealers |work=Los Angeles Times |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/sep/20/opinion/oe-westwater20 |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> On October 3, 2006, police arrested Skid Row's transients for sleeping on the streets for the first time in months.<ref>{{cite web |date=2007-10-03 |title=LAPD Gentrifies Skid Row |publisher=Colorlines |url=http://colorlines.com/archives/2007/10/lapd_gentrifies_skid_row.html |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> On October 10, 2006, under pressure from the ACLU, the city tacitly agreed to the compromise by declining to appeal the court's decision.<ref name=respite/>
==Demographics== As of the [[census]]<ref name="GR2">{{cite web |title=American FactFinder |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]] |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov |accessdate=2008-01-31}}</ref> of 2000, there were 17,740 people and 2,410 households residing in the neighborhood. The [[population density]] was 4,111/mi². The 2017 racial makeup of the neighborhood was 12% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 62% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 1% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 1% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 21% [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]], 0.3% [[Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States_Census|Native Hawaiian / Other Pacific Islander]], and 2% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]]. <ref>{{cite web|title=2017 Greater Los Angeles Homeless Count - Data Summary - Skid Row|url=https://www.lahsa.org/documents?id=1464-2017-greater-los-angeles-homeless-count-data-summary-skid-row.pdf|website=LAHSA|accessdate=5 November 2017}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.laalmanac.com/population/po24la.htm Race Demographics: L.A. Almanac] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111043420/http://www.laalmanac.com/population/po24la.htm |date=2010-01-11 }}</ref>{{Notinsourcegiven|date=December 2016}}
In the neighborhood the population was spread out with 9.8% under the age of 18, 54.7% from 18 to 34, 39.9% from 35 to 64, and 4.6% who were 65 years of age or older.<ref>[http://www.laalmanac.com/LA/la01a.htm Age and Sex Demographics: L.A. Almanac]</ref>{{Notinsourcegiven|date=December 2016}}
The [[per capita income]] for the neighborhood was $14,210. About 41.8% of the population were below the [[poverty line]].<ref>[http://www.laalmanac.com/LA/la11c.htm Poverty by neighborhood: L.A. Almanac]</ref>{{Notinsourcegiven|date=December 2016}}
==Government and infrastructure== The [[Los Angeles Fire Department]] (LAFD) serves the neighborhood with Station No. 3 in the Business District, one in the West and Station No. 9 in Skid Row. Station No. 9 operates one engine, one truck, two [[Advanced life support|ALS]] rescue ambulances, and one [[Basic life support|BLS]] rescue ambulance. It currently is the busiest firehouse in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lafd.blogspot.com/2007/08/busiest-fire-stations-in-los-angeles.html |title=LAFD News & Information: The Busiest Fire Stations in Los Angeles |publisher=Lafd.blogspot.com |date=2007-08-04 |accessdate=2013-03-11}}</ref> Fire engines and ambulances serving the neighborhood have historically had "Skid Row" emblazoned on their sides.<ref name="firestation9skidrow1">[http://www.firestation9skidrow.com/help.html Fire Station 9 Skid Row] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929033644/http://www.firestation9skidrow.com/help.html |date=2007-09-29 }}</ref> On June 1, 2006, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reported that fire officials planned to change the legend on the vehicles to read "Central City East". Many residents supported the change, but it was opposed by firefighters and some residents who take pride in the sense that they live in a tough area.<ref name="firestation9skidrow1"/>
The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] operates the Central Health Center in [[Downtown Los Angeles]], serving Skid Row.<ref>"[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/central.pdf Central Health Center]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved March 18, 2010.</ref>
Services for homeless people in Los Angeles are centralized in Skid Row.<ref name="Hunter1993">{{cite book|author=Juanita K. Hunter|title=Nursing and Health Care for the Homeless|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=egn5Vl_6JZQC&pg=PA34|accessdate=25 May 2013|year=1993|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-1-4384-0731-9|page=34}}</ref> Examples include the [[Volunteers of America]], the [[Union Rescue Mission]], The Jonah Project, Downtown Mental Health (a branch of the Department of Mental Health), LAMP, Downtown Women's Center, The Weingart Foundation, Los Angeles Mission, Fred Jordan Mission, The Society of St. Vincent de Paul's Cardinal Manning Center,<ref>[http://svdpla.org/index.php/cardinalmanning/contents/about_cardinal_manning_center Svdpla.org]</ref> and [[Midnight Mission]]. In 2007, Union Rescue Mission opened Hope Gardens, a facility outside of Skid Row which is exclusively for women and children.<ref>[http://www.hopegardens.org/ Hope Gardens Family Center]</ref>
==Landmarks== <!-- If at all possible, please only include blue-linked landmarks in here with citations that explicitly state that they're located in the Skid Row district--> [[File:Phase 1 of Skid Row Super Mural.jpg|thumb|300px|The Skid Row City Limits Mural]]
*[[Star Apartments]], a residential housing complex opened in October 2012, built specifically for the needs of the homeless.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lowery|first1=Wesley|title=Innovative housing for the homeless being built in downtown L.A.|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/dec/16/local/la-me-skid-row-housing-20121216|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref> *[[Indian Alley]] is the unofficial name given to a stretch of alley, in reference to the significance the area held for indigent [[American Indians in the United States|American Indians]] from the 1970s to the 1990s.<ref name="Frazier">{{cite book|last=Frazier|first=Ian|title=On the Rez|year=2000|publisher=Macmillan|location=New York|isbn=0374226385|pages=134, 135}}</ref> Indian Alley comprises a block of Werdin Place, running south from Winston Street to East 5th Street. It is bounded to the west by Main Street and to the east by [[Los Angeles Street]].<ref name="Frazier" /> *The [[Skid Row City Limits Mural]] is an 18-by-50-foot mural displayed at San Julian Street, created in 2014. It features a map demarcating Skid Row's officially recognized boundaries alongside an official-looking sign, replete with city seal, reading "Skid Row City Limit, Population: Too Many." This is the initial installation of a mural project that is planned to eventually cover the whole wall on the San Julian block north of 6th Street. Installed in compliance with the city's mural ordinance, the project was organized by Skid Row activist General Jeff Page with local street art crew Winston Death Squad, and carried out with the labor of Skid Row citizens. Los Angeles City Councilman Jose Huizar's office has hailed the mural, saying, "It's community pride on the one hand, it's cleverly done and it creates conversation and debate, which often great public art does." <ref>{{cite web|last1=Schaefer|first1=Samantha|title=For Skid Row Residents and Advocates, Mural is a Sign of Survival|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/la-me-skid-row-mural-20140824-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Romero|first1=Dennis|title=Skid Row Gets City Recognition Through Murals|url=http://www.laweekly.com/informer/2014/08/06/skid-row-gets-city-recognition-through-murals-photos|website=LA Weekly|publisher=LA Weekly|accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
==In popular culture== [[File:If you lived here, you'd be home now.jpg|thumb|right|A man sleeps in a shopping cart on Skid Row, 2012.]] The site has appeared as a location in several movies, including ''[[The Sting]]'', and television shows such as ''[[Starsky & Hutch]]'', ''[[Baretta]]'', and ''[[Quincy ME]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Earliest Titles with Location Matching Werdon Pl.|url=https://www.imdb.com/search/title?%20E%205th%20St%2C%20Los%20Angeles%2C%20California%2C%20USA=&at=0&locations=Werdin%20Pl%20&sort=year|publisher=Internet Movie Database}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Starsky & Hutch, The Psychic Filming Locations|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0709571/locations?ref_=tt_dt_dt|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Baretta, Keep Your Eye on the Sparrow Filming Locations|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0518716/locations?ref_=tt_dt_dt|publisher=Internet Movie Database}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Quincy, Dark Angel Filming Locations|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0681765/locations?ref_=tt_dt_dt|publisher=Internet Movie Database}}</ref> The 1960 [[comedy horror]] film ''[[The Little Shop of Horrors]]'' is set in Skid Row; however, the location of the [[Little Shop of Horrors (musical)|1982 musical]] (and its [[Little Shop of Horrors (1986 film)|1986 film adaptation]]) was moved to [[New York City]] (although the song ''Skid Row (Downtown)'' exists in both).
Skid Row was also used as a location for filming the music video for the [[Michael Jackson]] song "[[Beat It]]".<ref>{{cite web|first= Lindsay |last= Blake |title= The (Probable) Warehouse from Michael Jackson's "Beat It" Video |url= http://www.iamnotastalker.com/2010/03/26/the-probable-warehouse-from-michael-jacksons-beat-it/ |publisher= Iamnotastalker.com |date= March 26, 2010 |accessdate= September 21, 2010}}</ref>
The [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[Skid Row (American band)|Skid Row]] was named after this area.
American singer-songwriter [[Lana Del Rey]] mentions the area in her 2012 song [[Cola (Lana Del Rey song)|Cola]], in the lyric "I wear my diamonds on Skid Row."
Electronic artist [[James Ferraro]]'s album [[Skid Row (James Ferraro album)|Skid Row]] is conceptualized around the area.
==Notable residents== <!-- If at all possible, please only include blue-linked people in here with citations that explicitly state how they're associated with the Skid Row district--> *[[Johnnie Ray]] – singer, songwriter, and pianist. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=d0caAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3CMEAAAAIBAJ&dq=los-angeles%20skid-row&pg=4778%2C4738993|title=Crying Singer Would Credit Faith For Climb Up Ladder|publisher=The Times-News|date=October 13, 1952|author=Aline Mosby|accessdate=May 26, 2013}}</ref> * [[Danny Harris]] – Olympic hurdler and silver medalist.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/jul/27/sports/sp-streeter27|title=Addiction turned out to be his biggest hurdle|publisher=The Times-News|date=July 27, 2008|author=Kurt Streeter|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref> * [[George Takei]] and family – Japanese-American actor, director, author, and activist.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.startalkradio.net/all-access/george-takei-legacy-star-trek/?_sf_s=george+takei&post_types=all-access&_sft_category=episode|title=George Takei and the Legacy of Star Trek - StarTalk Radio Show by Neil deGrasse Tyson|newspaper=StarTalk Radio Show by Neil deGrasse Tyson|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-18}}</ref> * [[Lil Peep]] (deceased) — an [[United States|American]] rapper whose first mixtapes were "largely recorded in his skid row apartment". <ref>http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-lil-peep-obituary-20171116-story.html</ref>
==Transportation== The community is served primarily by 10 [[Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] bus lines:<ref>[http://www.metro.net/riding_metro/maps/system_map.pdf Metro System Map]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===Local lines===
'''Line 16/316''' — Downtown Los Angeles to [[Century City, Los Angeles, California|Century City]] ''(via Fifth and Sixth streets)''
'''Line 18''' — [[Koreatown, Los Angeles, California|Koreatown]] to [[Montebello/Commerce (Metrolink station)|Montebello]] ''(via Fifth and Sixth streets)''
'''Line 20''' — Downtown Los Angeles to [[Westwood, Los Angeles, California|Westwood]] ''(via Seventh Street)''
'''Line 51''' — [[Compton, California|Compton]] to [[Wilshire/Vermont (LACMTA station)|Wilshire/Vermont Station]] ''(via Seventh and San Pedro streets)''
'''Line 52/352''' — [[Harbor Gateway Transit Center]] to Wilshire/Vermont Station ''(via Seventh Street, San Pedro Street, and Avalon Boulevard)''
'''Line 53''' — [[California State University, Dominguez Hills]] to Downtown Los Angeles ''(via Fifth and Sixth streets)''
'''Line 60''' — [[Artesia (LACMTA station)|Artesia Station]] to Downtown Los Angeles ''(via Seventh Street)''
'''Line 62''' — [[Hawaiian Gardens, California|Hawaiian Gardens]] to Downtown Los Angeles ''(via Fifth and Sixth streets)''
===Rapid lines=== {{Main|Metro Rapid}}
'''Metro Rapid Line 720''' — [[Commerce (Metrolink station)|Commerce]] to [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]] ''(via Fifth and Sixth streets)''
'''Metro Rapid Line 760''' — [[Artesia (LACMTA station)|Artesia Station]] to Downtown Los Angeles ''(via Seventh Street)''
==See also== {{Portal|Los Angeles}} *[[Skid row]] *[[Deinstitutionalisation]] *[[Los Angeles Poverty Department]]
==Further reading== *''Down, Out, and Under Arrest: Policing and Everyday Life in Skid Row'' by Forrest Stuart, 2016, University of Chicago Press
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{commons category|Skid Row, Los Angeles}} * [http://www.homelessboundla.com ''Homeless Bound LA Skid Row''] A cinéma-vérité film by Michael C. Clark about homelessness on Skid Row in Los Angeles, interlaced with interviews of the homeless inhabitants. Shot in Spring of 2013. * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/14/AR2007031402271.html L.A. Police Initiative Thins Out Skid Row] - ''[[Washington Post]]'' * [http://www.lachamber.com/clientuploads/LUCH_committee/102208_History_of_Skid_Row.pdf History of Skid Row], published by the [[Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce]] * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2259392/ ''Lost Angels''] A 2010 documentary picturing a number of inhabitants of Skid Row
<!--spacing-->
{{Downtown Los Angeles|state=collapsed}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Solomon Andrews | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1835|04|05}} | birth_place = [[Trowbridge]], Wiltshire | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1908|11|09|1835|04|05}} | death_place = | known_for = | occupation = }}
'''Solomon Andrews''' (5 April 1835 – 9 November 1908) was a British entrepreneur and head of the Solomon Andrews and Son bus and tram-operating company, based in [[Cardiff]].
==Family== Andrews was born in [[Trowbridge]], Wiltshire, the son of John Andrews and Charlotte. The fourth of six children, he was baptised on 5 June 1835 in St James's Church, Trowbridge.<ref>Parish Registers of the church of St. James, Trowbridge</ref>
On 27 March 1855, Solomon married Mary Asher (20 August 1832 – 18 January 1870), daughter of John and Mary Asher, in Trinity Church, Trowbridge. There were five children from the marriage but only two survived infancy: * Mary Lillah Asher Andrews (24 June 1857) married John McRae June 1880 in Cardiff and she died 13 Mar 1929 *Francis Emile Andrews (29 September 1858 – 30 November 1943)
His second wife, whom he married on 15 June 1870 in Knighton Parish Church, was Mary Jane Udell (born 2 March 1849) of Wrexham.<ref>Wiltshire Times, 14 November 1908</ref> There were six children from this marriage: *Beatrice Andrews (6 April 1871) *Herbert Fletcher Andrews (16 April 1873 – 8 June 1874) *Florence Andrews *May Andrews, married William Edgar Clogg *Daisy Andrews *Sydney Solomon Andrews (26 February 1885)
==Career== By 1851 Andrews was living in [[Cardiff]], at 17 Tredegar Street, and working as a baker and confectioner.<ref>The Wiltshire archaeological and natural history magazine: Volume 36, Wiltshire Archaeological and Natural History Society – 1910</ref> The house was owned by George and Charlotte Asher, George being a baker and confectioner, so Solomon was presumably learning the trade.
On 24 November 1856 he leased a shop and house at 51 James Street.
On 17 December 1863<ref>Keep Moving. The Story of Solomon Andrews and His Family, John F. Andrews, November 1976. {{ISBN|0 900807 23 7}}</ref> he obtained a licence to operate a horse-drawn cab from the new residential districts of Canton and Roath to [[Cardiff Docks]]. By 1865, he had eight cabs and he is thought to have been an omnibus proprietor by December 1866.
His business interests grew rapidly to include tramways, buses, draperies and collieries.
His son Francis Emile (1858–1943) joined the company and eventually became a partner, the business becoming known as ''Solomon Andrews and Son'',
==Transport== ===Buses=== [[File:Star Omnibus Company horse bus, 2010 Cobham bus rally.jpg|thumb|Star Omnibus Company horse bus at the 2010 Cobham bus rally]] He was best known for the Andrews Star Omnibus Company and the [[Star Omnibus Company]] (London) which provided horse-drawn bus services in London. His company also ran buses in: *[[Belfast]] *[[Leicester]] *[[Manchester]] *[[Nottingham]]
===Trams=== *Cardiff *[[Plymouth]] *[[Portsmouth]] – [[Portsmouth Street Tramways Company]] *[[Pwllheli]] – [[Pwllheli and Llanbedrog Tramway]] *Barmouth Junction – [[Barmouth Junction and Arthog Tramway]]
==Property== ===Arthog=== [[File:Mawddach Crescent - geograph.org.uk - 985246.jpg|thumb|Mawddach Crescent]] [[File:St Mary's Terrace Arthog - geograph.org.uk - 392611.jpg|thumb|St Mary's Terrace, Arthog]] [[File:Arthog - geograph.org.uk - 245796.jpg|thumb|Arthog Terrace]] In 1894 he purchased an area near [[Arthog]] consisting of several farms. He developed three terraces of houses, including St Mary's Terrace, Arthog Terrace, and Mawddach Crescent.
Mawddach Crescent was a row of properties overlooking the [[River Mawddach|Mawddach estuary]]. The Crescent was connected to [[Morfa Mawddach railway station|Barmouth Junction railway station]] by the short-lived [[Barmouth Junction and Arthog Tramway]] which he constructed. Andrews intended this to be the start of a purpose-built holiday resort but the surrounding land proved unsuitable for further construction. In 1941, during the [[Second World War]], the Crescent was commandeered by the [[Royal Marines]]. It was renamed Camp Iceland and used as a training facility.
St Mary's Terrace in Arthog was also served by the [[Barmouth Junction and Arthog Tramway]].
===Aberdovey=== Andrews purchased land here and started work by fencing off some of it. However, this provoked trouble locally as public rights of way were affected, so no development ever took place. The land was later sold to the local authority.
===Cardiff=== Andrews undertook the rebuilding of 10 Bute Street (now Hayes Bridge Road) in 1871. This building was intended to be a grocery and confectionery shop and the headquarters of the Solomon Andrews and Son firm.
In the 1870s the expansion of his omnibus business led to the acquisition of new sites for depots. A freehold site was purchased at Severn Road, Canton, in 1875, and a manager's house, bus shed, stables and workshops was constructed.
In 1875, he also undertook work on a leasehold site at Glebe Street, Penarth. In 1880 he built a tram car depot at the junction of Ferry Road and Clive Street, Grangetown. This was for the Cardiff District and Penarth Harbour Tramway Company which opened in 1881.
Between 1881–83 Andrews built five houses and shops, five cottages and Windsor Hall in Holmesdale Street, and some houses in Earl Street. Andrews Terrace in Ferry Road, consisting of sixteen houses and a coffee tavern, was also constructed at around the same time.
In 1884 he constructed the Market Buildings in St Mary Street, Cardiff at a cost of some £12,000. Sadly this building was destroyed by fire in June 1885, and it had been replaced by September 1886,<ref>The Pictorial World, 9 December 1886</ref> the new building being constructed with eight-inch-thick concrete flooring to prevent further fires.
In 1885 in James Street he began construction of Mercantile Buildings which survived until demolished in the 1970s during a road widening scheme.
In 1888 Andrews completed the Imperial Buildings on St Mary Street, Cardiff, which became known as Barry's Hotel.
He also built two streets of housing which were named Mary Street and Solomon Street (later renamed Andrews Road), and was involved in the construction of warehouses on the southern side of Penarth Road, as well as between Crawshay Lane (now Curran Road) and Trade Street. Terraced houses were built from the corner of Blaenclydach Street south-westwards along Penart Road in 1891 to designs by the architect E.W.M. Corbett.
The Atlas, or Hayes, Building was erected around 1893 and this survived until destroyed by fire in 1958.
In 1894 Andrews constructed residential property from 75 to 113 Penarth Road, and the Andrews' Buildings on Queen Street to designs by the architect Edward Webb.
In 1895 the firm started building work in Penarth. Andrews' Buildings (Penarth), erected in 1896, consisted of five shops fronting Stanwell Road, a corner shop and two shops in Windsor Terrace. In 1897 the company built Lloyds Bank on the corner of Windsor Road and Albert Road to designs by the architect Edward Webb. This was followed by the Windsor Arcade, a row of shops on Windsor Road.
Around 1900 Metropole Buildings, 3–7 The Hayes, Cardiff was erected. This building was badly damaged by an air raid in the Second World War, but was reconstructed in 1959.
Numbers,11, 12, and 13 Bute Street (now Hayes Bridge Road) were rebuilt in 1902 to designs by the architect Lennox Robertson. Andrews also constructed Pembroke Buildings on Pembroke Terrace in the same year, using the architect E.W.M. Corbett.
===Pwllheli=== [[File:Promenâd Pwllheli Promenade - geograph.org.uk - 346014.jpg|thumb|Pwllheli Promenade]] In [[Pwllheli]], Andrews was responsible for the development of the West End holiday resort, which included a promenade, housing, roads, a recreation ground, golf course, and the West End Hotel. The stone required to build the West End was provided by a local quarry that he leased at Carreg-y-defaid. The company constructed the [[Pwllheli and Llanbedrog Tramway]], which carried the stone and passengers.
The West End Hotel was constructed first, along with large houses numbered 1–4 The Parade. The hotel was probably completed by 1895 and the houses in 1896. The construction was mostly in concrete, with the joinery being provided by his workshops in Cardiff and delivered to Pwllheli by rail.
Further building work was undertaken in 1897 when plans for nos 5–10 The Parade were approved by the council. Nos 11–16 followed quickly afterwards and all were completed by 1899.
Construction of housing and shops in Cardiff Road was undertaken between 1897 and 1901. A power station was erected next to the Assembly Rooms behind the West End Hotel, to provide electrical power for the West End Hotel.<ref>History of the Gas Industry in Pwllheli, W. N. Thomas.</ref>
<!-- ===Penarth=== -->
==Retail== *David Evans. [[Department store]] in [[Swansea]]. Eventually owned by [[House of Fraser]]. *David Evans and Co. Department store in Cardiff. *Evan Jones and Co. Men's outfitter's in Cardiff.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Andrews, Solomon}} [[Category:1835 births]] [[Category:1908 deaths]] [[Category:British bakers]] [[Category:People from Trowbridge]] [[Category:British businesspeople]]

revision.text:
{{howto|date=August 2016}} '''Stakeholder management''' is a critical component to the successful delivery of any project, programme or activity. A [[Project stakeholders|stakeholder]] is any individual, group or organization that can affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a programme.<ref name="Stakeholder Identification">{{cite book |last1=Sowden |first1=Rod |last2=Office |first2=Cabinet |date=August 30, 2011 |title=Managing successful programmes |publisher=Stationery Office |page=59| isbn=9780113313273 }}</ref> Stakeholder management creates positive relationships with stakeholders through the appropriate management of their expectations and agreed objectives. Stakeholder management is a process and control that must be planned and guided by underlying principles. Stakeholder management within businesses, organizations, or projects prepares a [[strategy]] using information (or intelligence) gathered during the following common processes.
==Stakeholder identification== {{main|Stakeholder analysis}} The first step in your stakeholder analysis is to brainstorm who your stakeholders are. As part of this, think of all the people who are affected by your work, who have influence or power over it, or have an interest in its successful or unsuccessful conclusion. Remember that although stakeholders may be both [[organization]]s and [[people]], ultimately you must communicate with people. Make sure that you identify the correct individual stakeholders within a stakeholder organization.<ref name="Prioritize Your Stakeholders">{{cite book |last1=Sowden |first1=Rod |last2=Office |first2=Cabinet |date=August 30, 2011 |title=Managing successful programmes |publisher=Stationery Office |page=64| isbn=9780113313273 }}</ref>
So in a nutshell, the stakeholder management comprises four steps:<ref name="Stakeholder management">{{cite web|url=http://knowledge.apm.org.uk/bok/stakeholder-management |title=APM Knowledge Stakeholder management |author=Association for Project Management (APM)}}</ref>
* Identify, recognize and acknowledge stakeholder; * Determine their influence and interest; * Establish [[communication management]] plan * Influencing and engaging stakeholder
==Stakeholder prioritization == You may now have a long list of people and organizations that are affected by your work. Some of these may have the power either to block or advance. Some may be interested in what you are doing, others may not care. Map out your stakeholders on a Power/Interest Grid, and classify them by their power over your work and by their interest in your work. There are other tools available to map out your stakeholders and how best to influence them.
For example, your boss is likely to have high power and influence over your projects and high interest. Your family may have high interest, but are unlikely to have power over it. Someone's position on the grid shows you the actions you have to take with them: *'''High power, interested people:''' these are the people you must fully engage and make the greatest efforts to satisfy. *'''High power, less interested people:''' put enough work in with these people to keep them satisfied, but not so much that they become bored with your message. *'''Low power, interested people:''' keep these people adequately informed, and talk to them to ensure that no major issues are arising. These people can often be very helpful with the detail of your project. *'''Low power, less interested people:''' again, monitor these people, but do not bore them with excessive communication.
==Understanding your key stakeholders== You now need to know more about your key stakeholders. You need to know how they are likely to feel about and react to your project. You also need to know how best to engage them in your project and how best to communicate with them. Key questions that can help you understand your stakeholders are: *What financial or emotional interest do they have in the outcome of your work? Is it positive or negative? *What motivates them most of all? *What information do they want from you? *How do they want to receive information from you? What is the best way of communicating your message to them? *What is their current opinion of your work? Is it based on good information? *Who influences their opinions generally, and who influences their opinion of you? Do some of these influencers therefore become important stakeholders in their own right? *If they are not likely to be positive, what will win them around to support your project? *If you don't think you will be able to win them around, how will you manage their opposition? *Who else might be influenced by their opinions? Do these people become stakeholders in their own right?
==Key principles of stakeholder engagement== * Communicate: To ensure intended message is understood and the desired response achieved. * Consult, early and often: To get the useful information and ideas, ask questions. * Remember, they are human: Operate with an awareness of human feelings. * Plan it: Time investment and careful planning against it, has a significant payoff. * Relationship: Try to engender trust with the stakeholders. * Simple but not easy: Show your care. Be empathetic.Listen to the stakeholders. * [[Risk management|Managing risk]]: Stakeholders can be treated as risk and opportunities that have probabilities and impact. * Compromise: Compromise across a set of stakeholders' diverging priorities. * Understand what is success: Explore the value of the project to the stakeholder. * Take responsibility: Project governance is the key of project success
Source: <ref name="Stakeholder engagement">{{cite web|url=https://www.apm.org.uk/stakeholder-engagement |title=Stakeholder engagement |author=Association for Project Management (APM)}}</ref>
==Organizational stakeholders== It is well acknowledged that any given organization will have multiple stakeholders including, but not limited to, customers, shareholders, employees, suppliers, and so forth. Within the field of marketing, it is believed that customers are one of the most important stakeholders for managing its long-term value, with a firm's major objective being the management of customer satisfaction.<ref>Gordon E. Greenley and Gordon R. Foxall. (2003). Multiple Stakeholder Orientation in UK Companies and the Implications for Company Performance. ''Journal of Management Studies, 34'', 259–284.</ref>
==Engaging and communicating with stakeholders==
With a clear understanding of your Stakeholders, engaging and communicating can be achieved through a variety of channels based upon who the stakeholder is.<ref name="Managing Stakeholder Expectations">{{cite web |url=http://www.pmiglc.org/PD/Uploads/PMIGreatLakesChapter_Dec2011Forum_GMoore.pdf |last=Moore |first=Gwendolyn |date=December 12, 2011 |title=PMI Great Lakes Chapter Forum, Tools and Techniques for Managing Stakeholder Expectations |page=8}}</ref> *'''High power, interested people:''' Manage closely. Best channels: [[Issue Log|Issue]], Change Logs, Status Meetings *'''High power, less interested people:''' Keep satisfied. Best channels: Steering Committee, Board Meeting Updates *'''Low power, interested people:''' Keep informed. Best channels: In-Person, Video, Email Updates *'''Low power, less interested people:''' Monitor. Best channels: Send Email, Status Reports
== See also == *[[Stakeholder register]] *[[Project stakeholder]] *[[Stakeholder analysis]] *[[Responsibility assignment matrix]]
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== * {{cite journal |title=Does Stakeholder Orientation Matter? The Relationship Between Stakeholder Management Models and Firm Financial Performance |journal=Academy of Management Journal |volume=42 |issue=5 |pages=488 |year=1999 |last1=Berman |first1=S. L |last2=Wicks |first2=A. C |last3=Kotha |first3=S |last4=Jones |first4=T. M |doi=10.2307/256972 |jstor=256972}} * {{cite journal |last1=Bourne |first1=Lynda |last2=Walker |first2=Derek H.T |year=2008 |title=Project relationship management and the Stakeholder Circle™ |journal=International Journal of Managing Projects in Business |volume=1 |pages=125 |doi=10.1108/17538370810846450}} * {{cite journal |title=Proactive environmental strategies: A stakeholder management perspective |journal=Strategic Management Journal |volume=24 |issue=5 |pages=453 |year=2003 |last1=Buysse |first1=Kristel |last2=Verbeke |first2=Alain |doi=10.1002/smj.299}} * {{cite book revision.text:
{{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = The ONE Thing: The Surprisingly Simple Truth Behind Extraordinary Results | image = File:The_ONE_Thing_book_cover.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Gary W. Keller]] and [[Jay Papasan]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = {{flat list | *[[Non-fiction]] *[[Self-help]] }} | set_in = | published = | publisher = Bard Press | publisher2 = | pub_date = April 1, 2013 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 240 | awards = | isbn = 978-1885167774 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = [http://www.the1thing.com/ Official website] }}
'''''The ONE Thing: The Surprisingly Simple Truth Behind Extraordinary Results''''' is a [[non-fiction]], [[self-help]] book written by [[authors]] and [[Real estate entrepreneur|real estate entrepreneurs]], [[Gary W. Keller]] and [[Jay Papasan]].<ref name="Forbes">{{cite news | last=Schawbel| first=Dan| title =Gary Keller: How To Find Your One Thing| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = ''[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]''| date =23 May 2013 | url =https://www.forbes.com/sites/danschawbel/2013/05/23/gary-keller-how-to-find-your-one-thing/#4c6cc9f228da| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="PW">{{cite news | last=| first=| title =The One Thing: The Surprisingly Simple Truth Behind Extraordinary Results | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = ''[[Publishers Weekly]]''| date =25 February 2013 | url =http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-885167-77-4| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="PStar">{{cite news | last=Osorio| first=Bong R.| title =The one thing that matters most | newspaper =[[The Philippine Star]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =10 January 2016 | url =http://www.philstar.com/business-life/2016/01/11/1541187/one-thing-matters-most| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> The book discusses the value of simplifying one's workload by focusing on the one most important task in any given project.<ref name="GM">{{cite news | last=Schachter| first=Harvey| title =Behind every success is one big thing. Here's how to find yours | newspaper =[[The Globe and Mail]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =14 March 2013 | url =https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/careers/career-advice/life-at-work/behind-every-success-is-one-big-thing-heres-how-to-find-yours/article9774792/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Huff7">{{cite news | last=Ayling| first=Tom| title =The 7 Principles I Use To Stay Mentally Sharp | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[The Huffington Post]] | date =12 February 2016 | url =http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tom-ayling/the-7-principles-i-use-to_b_9073758.html| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="ExTrib">{{cite news | last=Shahid| first=Umnia| title =6 conventional life rules successful people break all the time | newspaper =[[The Express Tribune]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =20 March 2016 | url =http://tribune.com.pk/story/1069430/6-conventional-life-rules-successful-people-break-all-the-time/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> The book has appeared on the best seller lists of ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name="NYT">{{cite news | last=| first=| title =Best Sellers: Advice and How-To: Sunday, May 12th 2013 | newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =12 May 2013 | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9405EEDF173EF931A25756C0A9659D8B63| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',<ref name="WSJ">{{cite news | last=| first=| title =Best-Selling Books, Week Ended April 28 | newspaper =[[The Wall Street Journal]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =3 May 2013 | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323628004578456722639384656| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> ''[[USA Today]]'', and [[Amazon.com]].<ref name="Howes">{{cite interview |last=Papasan |first=Jay |subject-link= |interviewer=[[Lewis Howes]]|title=The One Thing That Will Transform Your Productivity with Jay Papasan |url=http://lewishowes.com/podcast/jay-papasan/ |date=13 May 2015 |work=[[The School of Greatness]] |access-date=24 May 2016}}</ref> The book was first published by Bard Press on April 1, 2013.<ref name="PW"/>
==Background==
Gary Keller is the co-founder and Chairman of the Board at [[Keller Williams Realty]], which is one of the world's largest [[real estate]] companies.<ref name="Forbes"/><ref name="Burg">{{cite interview |last=Keller |first=Gary |subject-link= |interviewer=Bob Burg|title=The ONE Thing – An Interview with Gary Keller |url=http://www.burg.com/2013/04/the-one-thing-an-interview-with-gary-keller/ |date=15 April 2013 |access-date=24 May 2016}}</ref> Jay Papasan is the Vice President of publishing at Keller Williams. Prior to the publication of ''The ONE Thing'' in 2013, the two collaborated on ''The Millionaire Real Estate'' series of books which discussed how to invest in and earn money from real estate properties.<ref name="Forbes"/><ref name="Howes"/><ref name="Indie">{{cite news | last=Coles Johnson| first=Donna Maria| title =November 2013 Indie Business Book Club: The ONE Thing by Gary Keller and Jay Papasan | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =Indie Business Network | date =1 November 2013 | url =http://www.indiebusinessnetwork.com/book-club-the-one-thing-by-indie-business-network-founder-and-ceo-donna-maria/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> ''The ONE Thing'' is the duo's first book that is not specifically focused on real estate. Instead, it discusses the general business principle of choosing a single task to work on to theoretically maximize the efficiency of that task and the overall project.<ref name="Kirkus">{{cite news | last=| first=| title =The One Thing| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]''| date =15 March 2013 | url =https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/gary-keller/the-one-thing/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Quartz">{{cite news | last=Elmer| first=Vickie| title =Forget the long to-do lists and choose one thing to be good at| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]| date =19 April 2013 | url =http://qz.com/75571/the-path-to-success-choose-one-thing-to-be-good-at/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Zoia">{{cite news | last=Zoia| first=Robert| title =The One Thing: The surprisingly simple truth behind extraordinary results, by Gary Keller (Book Review)| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =Zoia.org| date =15 January 2015 | url =http://zoia.org/2015/01/15/the-one-thing-the-surprisingly-simple-truth-behind-extraordinary-results-by-gary-keller-book-review/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref>
==Summary==
The book discusses the benefits of prioritizing a single task, and it also provides examples of how to engage in those tasks with a singular focus.<ref name="GM"/> The book begins with a section entitled, "The Lies: They Mislead and Derail Us," which analyzes the ways in which multitasking has erroneously been praised as a desirable trait.<ref name="Blu">{{cite news | last=| first=| title =The Business Book Review: The ONE Thing, Gary Keller| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =Blu Pagoda| date =5 May 2015 | url =http://www.blupagoda.com/blog/2015/5/5/the-business-book-review-the-one-thing-gary-keller| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> The authors also challenge the concept of "work-life balance", calling it "[i]dealistic, but not realistic."<ref name="PW"/>
This then leads to the "Focusing Question" which asks "What’s the ONE Thing I can do such that by doing it everything else will be easier or unnecessary?" This second section of the book deals with productivity principles like habit-building and benchmarking.<ref name="Blu"/> For instance, the book suggests that readers should engage in four hours of work on their "ONE thing" each day.<ref name="GM"/><ref name="Huff">{{cite news | last=Brady| first=Arlo| title =The ONE Thing | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[The Huffington Post]] | date =13 October 2013 | url =http://www.huffingtonpost.com/dr-arlo-brady/the-one-thing_1_b_3732007.html| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> The authors cite [[economist]] [[Vilfredo Pareto]] as one of the inspirations behind this philosophy. Pareto's principle suggested that 20% of the effort produces 80% of the results. According to the book, this means that engaging in the one most important task will be more likely to produce the desired results without any extraneous effort.<ref name="PStar"/><ref name="Quartz"/> The book also differentiates between the Big-Picture Question ("What’s my ONE Thing?") and the Small-Focus Question ("What’s my ONE Thing right now?").<ref name="Blu"/> The core idea is that focusing on an excessive amount of tasks will more likely lead to discord and under-performance.<ref name="BC">{{cite news | last=Maresca| first=Joseph S.| title =Book Review: The One Thing by Gary Keller, Jay Papasan | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[Blogcritics]] | date =18 May 2013 | url =http://blogcritics.org/book-review-the-one-thing-by/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Atiim">{{cite news | last=Rotenberg| first=Zorian| title =Book Insights from The ONE Thing by Gary Keller and Jay Papasan | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =Atiim| date =14 January 2016 | url =https://www.atiim.com/blog/the-one-thing-by-gary-keller-and-jay-papasan/| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref>
The third section of the book discusses "Extraordinary Results," which details how to make the above principles actionable. One of the concepts it illustrates is "time blocking," which means that one should focus on only their ONE thing during a given amount of time. It also suggests that readers should schedule time to reflect, plan, and even relax. Everything else during scheduled time blocks is characterized as a distraction. Each section of the book is followed up by a "Big Ideas" review that gives a summary of the sections' concepts and principles.<ref name="Blu"/><ref name="EntreTime">{{cite news | last=Vozza| first=Stephanie| title =Time Blocking: a Productivity Power Tool | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = ''[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]]''| date =8 April 2013 | url =https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/226231| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref>
==Critical reception==
''The ONE Thing'' garnered success both critically and commercially. It was listed as a best seller by ''The New York Times'',<ref name="NYT"/> ''The Wall Street Journal'',<ref name="WSJ"/> ''USA Today'', and Amazon.com.<ref name="Howes"/> [[Hudson Booksellers]] listed it among their best "Business Interest" books of 2013.<ref name="Hudson">{{cite news | last=| first=| title =Hudson Booksellers Announces the Best Books of 2013 | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = Digital Journal| date =12 November 2013 | url =http://www.digitaljournal.com/pr/1582146| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> In an article for ''[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]]'', Brandon Turner named ''The ONE Thing'' one of the "5 Powerful Books That Changed the Direction of My Life."<ref name="Entre5">{{cite news | last=Turner| first=Brandon| title =5 Powerful Books That Changed the Direction of My Life | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = ''[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]]''| date =25 March 2015 | url =https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/244123| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> In a review for ''[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]'', Alice Haine notes that the book "has the necessary ingredients to boost those feeling a little overwhelmed by the pressures of work and home life."<ref name="National">{{cite news | last=Haine| first=Alice| title =Actions speak louder than to-do lists | newspaper =''[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]''| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =24 July 2013 | url =http://www.thenational.ae/business/industry-insights/the-life/actions-speak-louder-than-to-do-lists| accessdate =24 May 2016}}</ref> A review on [[Blogcritics]] states "[t]his book will benefit management at virtually every level in an organization."<ref name="BC"/> ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' noted that book had "an appealing style and energy."<ref name="PW"/> It has won a total of 12 book awards and been translated into 26 languages. It was also voted one of the Top 100 Business Books of All Time on [[Goodreads]].
==References==
{{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.the1thing.com/ Official website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:One Thing}} [[Category:2013 non-fiction books]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Self-help books]]

'''The World Challenge''' is a competition that was first hosted in 2005 by [[BBC]] and sponsored by [[Newsweek]] and [[Shell Oil Company|Shell]]. It accepts projects from around the world that deal with [[society|social]], [[Social environment|environmental]] and [[community]] issues and uses [[business]] methods to try to improve upon those issues in the world.
== The 2005 winners == *1st prize: [[Coconets]], from a project in the [[Philippines]] called [[Juboken Enterprises]] *2nd and 3rd prize: [[Reef rehab]] and [[I Do Foundation]]
==The 2006 winners == *1st prize: [[Elephant paper]] by [[Maximus (Sri Lanka)]] *2nd and 3rd prize: [[Cards from Africa]] and [[NGO Dalit]]
==The 2007 winners == *1st prize: [[T'ikapapa]], Potato Goldmine project in [[Peru]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[School for Success]] and [[Cooking without Gas]]
==The 2008 winners == *1st prize: [[Hashoo Foundation]], Plan Bee project in [[Pakistan]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[A Chance to Grow]] and [[School for Success]]
==The 2009 winners == *1st prize: [[Safe Bottle Lamp]] Foundation, A Bright Idea project in [[Sri Lanka]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[Nothing Wasted]] and [[Fungi Town]]
==The 2009 winners == *1st prize: [[AIDFI]], The Only Way is Up project in the [[Philippines]]. *2nd and 3rd prize: [[A Class Apart]] and [[Pass it on]]
==Sources== *[http://www.theworldchallenge.co.uk/ http://www.theworldchallenge.co.uk]
{{DEFAULTSORT:World Challenge}} [[Category:Business and industry awards]] [[Category:Competitions]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2005]]
{{Business-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} [[Image:TABBourkeSt.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A TAB in [[Melbourne]]]] The '''Totalisator Agency Board''' in [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], universally shortened to '''TAB''' or '''T.A.B''', is the name given to monopoly [[totalisator]] organisations. All were originally government owned. In Victoria for instance, the State government owned Victorian Totalisator Agency Board began operating in March 1961.<ref>[http://guides.slv.vic.gov.au/content.php?pid=128214&sid=1100338#3567577 The Melbourne Cup Research Guide]</ref>
Most Australian TABs have been progressively privatised, beginning with Victoria in 1994.<ref>[http://www.tabcorp.com.au/about_history.aspx TABCorp history] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110224225407/http://www.tabcorp.com.au/about_history.aspx |date=24 February 2011 }}</ref>
TABs in Queensland, South Australia, Northern Territory and Tasmania were re-branded as [[Ubet, Wagering Company|UBET]] in 2015.<ref>[http://www.couriermail.com.au/business/tab-gets-makeover-with-hitech-ubet-store-to-open/news-story/59245464b438a92000bfa0c9886b7bf1 TAB gets a makeover to UBET]</ref>
The TABs have extensive radio networks in Australia, except in Victoria and Tasmania where other parties own equivalent networks. All these networks share the [[National Racing Service]], a continuous broadcast of [[horse racing|thoroughbred]], [[harness racing|harness]] and [[greyhound racing]]. This makes up the bulk of these networks' content. Collectively, these networks own more radio licences than any other group in Australia – however, their terrestrial coverage is less than the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] as they generally have tiny wattages.
The heir of the NSW TAB also owns a national racing subscription TV service. In New Zealand, the TAB owns a near-national free-to-air and national subscription TV service. Most New Zealanders can sit at their analogue TV with a standard aerial and watch racing.
The New Zealand TAB was replaced by the [[New Zealand Racing Board]] in 2003.
[[Radio TAB]] is also used to live sports coverage (including horse racing) in parts of Australia.
==See also== *[[Tatts Group]] *[[Tabcorp Holdings]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.tab.com.au TAB (Victoria/NSW/ACT)] *[https://ubet.com UBET (Queensland/South Australia/Northern Territory/Tasmania)] *[http://www.tabtouch.com.au/ TABtouch (Western Australia)] *[http://www.tab.co.nz TAB New Zealand]

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/80.23.94.126|80.23.94.126]] to version by Optakeover. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3395923) (Bot)
revision.text:
[[Image:CVP-TC-FC-VC.svg|thumb|right|240px|Decomposing [[Total Costs]] as [[Fixed Costs]] plus '''Variable Costs'''.]]
'''Variable costs''' are costs that change in proportion to the good or service that a business produces.<ref name="GNB pp 48">Garrison, Noreen, Brewer. Ch 2 - Managerial Accounting and Costs Concepts, pp 48</ref> Variable costs are also the sum of [[marginal cost]]s over all units produced. They can also be considered normal costs. [[Fixed cost]]s and variable costs make up the two components of [[total cost]]. '''Direct costs''', however, are costs that can easily be associated with a particular [[cost object]].<ref name="GNB pp 51">Garrison, Noreen, Brewer. Ch 2 - Managerial Accounting and Costs Concepts, pp 51</ref> However, not all variable costs are direct costs. For example, variable manufacturing [[Overhead (business)|overhead]] costs are variable costs that are [[indirect costs]], not direct costs. Variable costs are sometimes called unit-level costs as they vary with the number of units produced.
Direct labor and overhead are often called '''conversion cost''',<ref name="GNB pp 39">Garrison, Noreen, Brewer. Ch 2 - Managerial Accounting and Costs Concepts, pp 39</ref> while direct material and direct labor are often referred to as '''prime cost'''.<ref name="GNB pp 39" />
In [[marketing]], it is necessary to know how costs divide between variable and fixed. This distinction is crucial in forecasting the earnings generated by various changes in unit sales and thus the financial impact of proposed marketing campaigns. In a survey of nearly 200 senior marketing managers, 60 percent responded that they found the "variable and fixed costs" metric very useful.<ref name=Marketing_Metrics>Farris, Paul W.; Neil T. Bendle; Phillip E. Pfeifer; David J. Reibstein (2010). ''Marketing Metrics: The Definitive Guide to Measuring Marketing Performance.'' Upper Saddle River, New Jersey: Pearson Education, Inc. {{ISBN|0-13-705829-2}}. Content used from this source has been licensed under CC-By-SA and GFDL and may be reproduced verbatim. The [[Marketing Accountability Standards Board (MASB)]] endorses the definitions, purposes, and constructs of classes of measures that appear in ''Marketing Metrics'' as part of its ongoing [http://www.commonlanguage.wikispaces.net/ Common Language in Marketing Project].</ref>
The level of variable cost is influenced by many factors, such as [[fixed cost]], [[Duration (project management)|duration of project]], [[uncertainty]] and [[Interest rate|discount rate]]. An analytical formula of variable cost as a function of these factors has been derived. It can be used to assess how different factors impact variable cost and total return in an investment.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Unity of Science and Economics: A New Foundation of Economic Theory|last=Chen|first=Jing|publisher=Springer|year=2016|isbn=|location=https://www.springer.com/us/book/9781493934645|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
== Explanation == ===Example 1===
Assume a business produces clothing. A variable cost of this product would be the direct material, i.e., cloth, and the direct labor. If it takes one laborer 6 yards of cloth and 8 hours to make a shirt, then the cost of labor and cloth increases if two shirts are produced.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! !! 1 shirt !! 2 shirts !! 3 shirts |- | Cloth (Direct Materials) || 6yds || 12yds || 18yds |- | Labor (Direct Labor) || 8hrs || 16hrs || 24hrs |}
The amount of materials and labor that goes into each shirt increases in direct proportion to the number of shirts produced. In this sense, the cost "varies" as production varies.
===Example 2=== For example, a firm pays for [[raw materials]]. When activity is decreased, less raw material is used, and so the spending for raw materials falls. When activity is increased, more raw material is used, and spending therefore rises. Note that the changes in expenses happen with little or no need for managerial intervention. These costs are variable costs.
A company will pay for line rental and maintenance fees each period regardless of how much power gets used. And some electrical equipment (air conditioning or lighting) may be kept running even in periods of low activity. These expenses can be regarded as fixed. But beyond this, the company will use electricity to run plant and machinery as required. The busier the company, the more the plant will be run, and so the more electricity gets used. This extra spending can therefore be regarded as variable.
In retail the cost of goods is almost entirely a variable cost; this is not true of manufacturing where many fixed costs, such as depreciation, are included in the cost of goods.
Although taxation usually varies with profit, which in turn varies with sales volume, it is not normally considered a variable cost.
For some employees, salary is paid on monthly rates, independent of how many hours the employees work. This is a fixed cost. On the other hand, the hours of hourly employees can often be varied, so this type of labour cost is a variable cost. The cost of material is a variable cost.
==See also== {{colbegin}} * [[Cost]] * [[Fixed cost]] * [[Cost accounting]] * [[Cost curve]] * [[Cost driver]] * [[Semi variable cost]] * [[Total cost]] * [[Contribution margin]] {{colend}}
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== *<cite name="Garrison,Noreen,Brewer">{{cite book|last=Garrison|first=Ray H|author2=Eric W. Noreen |author3=Peter C. Brewer |title=Managerial Accounting|publisher=McGraw-Hill Irwin|edition=13e|isbn=978-0-07-337961-6|url=http://www.mhhe.com/garrison13e|year=2009}}</cite>
[[Category:Costs]] [[Category:Management accounting]] [[Category:Production economics]]
